revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye |native_name = |native_name_lang = |honorific-suffix = |colorcode = <!-- HTML color code (e.g. red, #FF0000 or affiliated Party metadata color template) or transparent for no coloring --> |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> |alt = |caption = |office = Rector of the [[Gaston Berger University]] |term_start = January 1990 |term_end = November 1999 |predecessor = |successor = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1937|05|20|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Saint-Louis, Senegal]] |death_date = |death_place = |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = |citizenship = |nationality = |party = |otherparty = <!--For additional political affiliations--> |spouse = |partner = <!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = |occupation = |profession = |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = {{url|http://membres.multimania.fr/ahmadoulamine/}} }} '''Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye''' (born 20 May 1937) is a former professor of Veterinary Sciences from [[Senegal]] who has held many senior administrative positions in African educational institutions and organizations.
==Birth and education== Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye was born on 20 May 1937 in [[Saint-Louis, Senegal]]. He attended the Lycée Faidherbe in Saint-Louis for his secondary education between 1950 and 1957. He studied at the Lycée Marcelin Berthelot de [[Saint-Maur-des-Fossés]], France for a year, and then was admitted to the National Veterinary School of Lyon (''Ecole Nationale Vétérinaire de Lyon''), where he studied from 1958 to 1962. In 1963 he gained diplomas from the Faculty of Medicine of Lyon, the National Agronomic Institute of Paris and the Institute of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Medicine in tropical countries.<ref name=ANSTSbio/>
==Teaching career==
Ndiaye worked at the Animal Science Research Center at Dahra, Senegal from 1963 to 1967, while completing an internship at the National Center for Agricultural Research [[Jouy-en-Josas]], France in the Genetics Section. In 1967 he became an assistant lecturer at the [[University of Dakar]]. In 1971 he became a trainee lecturer in food nutrition at the [[National Veterinary School of Alfort]] in France. In 1974 he became a fellow of this institute and a lecturer at the Inter-State School of Veterinary Sciences and Medicine of [[Dakar]].<ref name=ANSTSbio/> From 1976 to 1986 he was the first African director of the school, part of Dakar's [[Cheikh Anta Diop University]].<ref name=APS20110308/> In 1977 he was appointed a professor of animal nutrition, a position he held until 1988.<ref name=ANSTSbio/>
==Other appointments==
Ndiaye was a staff adviser to the President of the Republic of Senegal from 1988 to 1990. In January 1990 he was appointed Rector of the [[Gaston Berger University]] of Saint-Louis, the second university in Senegal, holding this position until November 1999. He was then Minister and special adviser to the President of the Republic for a few months.<ref name=ANSTSbio/>
Ndiaye was a member of the Executive Council of the [[Association of African Universities]] from 1997 to 2005, and for a period served as President of this association.<ref name=IRDbio/> He was the first president of the African Regional Committee for monitoring the World Conference on Higher Education (2000–2001). In 2002 he became a member of the [[World Bank]]'s Scientific Council for the reform of external training courses for higher education, and also Chairman of the Working Group for revitalization of the Institute of Natural Resources in Africa.<ref name=ANSTSbio/> Other positions held included member of the Academy of Sciences for the Developing World and founding member of the National Academy of Science and Technology of Senegal (ANSTS).<ref name=IRDbio/> In February 2011 Ndiaye was elected president of the ANSTS, replacing Professor Souleymane Niang who had recently died.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/201102211598.html |work=Agence de Presse Sénégalaise (Dakar) |title=Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye, nouveau président de l'Académie nationale des sciences et techniques |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref>
Ndiaye was appointed Chairman of the High Level Panel created in 2009 by the [[African Union]] to establish the [[Pan African University]] (PAU).<ref name=IRDbio/> The PAU is a network of universities across Africa that promotes post-graduate scientific education and research, mobility of students and teachers between institutions and standardization of qualifications, with five regional centers of excellence each focusing on a different area of science.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.notreafrik.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2803:ahmadou-lamine-ndiaye-lenseignement-superieur-victime-des-programmes-dajustement-structurel&catid=38:interview&Itemid=510 |title=Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye : L’enseignement Supérieur victime des programmes d’ajustement structurel |date=June 15, 2011 |work=Notre Afrik |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref> On 28 February 2011 Ndiaye was appointed President of the [[African Academy of Sciences]] (AAS) based in Nairobi, Kenya, for a three-year term. He was the first francophone to hold this position since the AAS was founded in 1985. Ndiaye said he wanted to rejuvenate the AAS, and felt that conditions were favorable. He aimed to open up centers of excellence on the continent where French and English speakers could work on joint research programs.<ref name=APS20110308/>
==Work and recognition==
Ndiaye has written over a hundred scientific articles, papers and reports, particularly in the areas of nutrition and higher education. He is also the author of more than thirty reports, such as one that [[UNESCO]] commissioned in 2009 on the Pan African University project. He is an Officer in the [[Mérite agricole|Order of Agricultural Merit of France]], Officer of the [[National Order of Ivory Coast]], Chevalier of the National Order of the Lion of Senegal and Grand Officer of the Order of Merit Senegal.<ref name=IRDbio/>
==References== {{reflist |refs= <ref name=ANSTSbio>{{cite web |url=http://www.asts.sn/asts/membre/cvasts/ahlan.htm |title=Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye |publisher=Academie Nationale des Sciences et Techniques du Senegal |accessdate=2011-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426014139/http://www.asts.sn/asts/membre/cvasts/ahlan.htm |archivedate=2012-04-26 }}</ref> <ref name=APS20110308>{{cite web |url=http://www.aps.sn/spip.php?article77756 |work=Agence de Presse Sénégalaise |title=Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye veut décloisonner les centres d’excellence du continent |date=8 March 2011 |author=Boubacar Kante |accessdate=2011-12-02 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> <ref name=IRDbio>{{cite web |url=http://www.ird.fr/l-ird/organigramme/instances-et-comites/le-comite-consultatif-de-deontologie-et-d-ethique/les-membres-du-comite/biographies/ahmadou-lamine-ndiaye |title=Ahmadou Lamine Ndiaye |publisher=Institute of Development Research |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref> }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ndiaye, Ahmadou Lamine}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Veterinary scientists]] [[Category:Senegalese scientists]] [[Category:Recipients of the National Order of the Ivory Coast]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Agricultural Merit]] [[Category:Knights of the National Order of the Lion]] [[Category:Cheikh Anta Diop University faculty]]

revision.text:
'''Akpan Okon''' was the last ''Obong'' (king) of [[Obong Okon Ita]] around 1690-1720. He was overthrown by his brother [[Kakpokpo Okon]] with the support of groups such as the [[Eze Agwu]], [[Nnachi Ipia]], and the [[Nnubi dynasty]] in the final phases of the [[Aro-Ibibio Wars]]. Akpan Okon's defeat was very significant and crucial to the alliance. The alliance between the Eze Agwu lineage and his ambitious brother Kakpokpo sealed his fate, defeated Obong Okon Ita, and laid the foundation of the [[Arochukwu]] kingdom.
==External links == *http://www.aro-okigbo.com/history_of_the_aros.htm *https://web.archive.org/web/20081121232256/http://www.aronetwork.org/others/arohistory.html *http://www.aronewsonline.com/origincivilization.html
[[Category:Aro people]] [[Category:18th-century rulers in Africa]] [[Category:18th-century Nigerian people]]
{{Nigeria-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Alys Robi | image = AlysRobi.jpg | alt = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Alice Robitaille | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|02|03}} | birth_place = [[Quebec City]], [[Quebec]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|05|28|1923|02|03}} | death_place = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada | origin = | instrument = [[Vocals]] | genre = [[Latin American music]] | occupation = | years_active = 1930–2011 | label = | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Alice Robitaille''' (February 3, 1923 – May 28, 2011), from [[Quebec City]], "petite Alys" (little Alys), was a French Canadian singer mainly remembered for her later French interpretations of Latin American songs, who performed under the [[stage name]] '''Alys Robi'''.
==Youth== Born in 1923 in the [[Quebec City]] neighbourhood of Saint-Sauveur, Robitaille displayed talent for singing and acting at a very young age. She first performed on-stage at the [[Capitol Theatre (Quebec)|Capitol Theatre]] at 7. At the time, she had already sung on-air with the [[CHRC (AM)|CHRC]] radio station and was a real phenomenon in the whole city.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web |title=Alice Robitaille: la grande Alys |publisher=City of Montreal |url=http://ville.montreal.qc.ca/portal/page?_pageid=2497,3090102&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL |accessdate=14 April 2010 |language=French}}</ref>
==Career== [[File:Radio. Tourbillon de la Gaieté. Alys Robi BAnQ Vieux-Montréal P48S1P23025.jpg|thumb|left|Robi performing for [[CKAC]] in 1943]] At 13 she moved to the Théâtre National, on [[Montreal]]'s [[Saint Catherine Street]].<ref name="Montreal"/> Under the direction of [[Rose Ouellette]], she learned acting and singing during a 75-week engagement. She continued her career in the Montreal [[cabaret]]s, making radio appearances. For a time during the war, she also hosted a French radio show named ''Tambour battant'' ("Rumbling drum"). Touring Canadian military bases propelled her career across Canada.<ref name="Montreal"/>
During the 1940s, she started producing [[Gramophone record|78]]s and she became renowned far beyond [[Canada]]. She captured popular imagination with [[Latin music (genre)|Latin]] titles like ''Besame Mucho'' and [[Tico-Tico no Fubá|''Tico tico'']], after translating herself the Spanish or Brazilian songs into French.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mort d'Alys Robi : Le destin hollywoodien de la première star mondiale du Québec |publisher=Pure People |url=http://www.purepeople.com/article/mort-d-alys-robi-le-destin-hollywoodien-de-la-premiere-star-mondiale-du-quebec_a80801/1 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |language=French}}</ref> She sang in chic [[New York City]] cabarets by the mid forties and in 1947, she travelled to [[England]] where she made an appearance on the first regular [[BBC]] television programme.
==Mental health== In 1948, while traveling by car to [[Hollywood]], she was injured in an accident, and entered a period of depression.<ref>{{cite web |title=Robi, Alys |publisher=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/alys-robi-emc/ <!--Bot repaired link--> |accessdate=14 April 2010}}</ref> After a series of unfortunate diagnoses, and a failed romance, she suffered a [[mental breakdown]] and was interned for several years in a Quebec City asylum.<ref name="Montreal"/> She was at some point subjected to a [[lobotomy]] against her will.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bittersweet memories |last=Hayter |first=Sparkle |publisher=''SEE'' magazine |url=http://www.seemagazine.com/Issues/2005/0721/screen2.htm |accessdate=14 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430180245/http://www.seemagazine.com/Issues/2005/0721/screen2.htm |archivedate=30 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> She credited the operation with her recovery:
''"Je me réveillai guérie et j'ai compris plus tard que j'avais été un des rares cas réussis de lobotomie"'' (I woke up better and later understood that I was one of the rare lobotomy success stories).<ref>''Long Cri dans la nuit: Cinq Années à l'Asile'', cited in [http://lamiredegisele.com/lecture/alysrobi/indexalys.html Alys Robi] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121070730/http://www.lamiredegisele.com/lecture/alysrobi/indexalys.html |date=2008-11-21 }}, lamiredegisele.com</ref> In 1952, she was released. The same year, she came back on stage at the Casa Loma and the Montmartre, but her efforts were impeded by [[taboo]]s about mental problems and she never regained the same level of popularity.
==Later years== In the early 1990s, Alys returned into the public eye after the massive success she had with a song written for her by Alain Morisod ("Laissez-moi encore chanter"). Books, [[Thesis|theses]], [[Play (theatre)|plays]] and [[television series]] were written about her. A movie was released in December 2004: ''Alys Robi: Ma vie en cinémascope'' ("Alys Robi: My Life in Cinemascope"), titled ''Bittersweet Memories'' in English.
Robitaille has published two [[autobiography|autobiographies]]: ''Ma carrière, ma vie'' ("My Career, My Life", 1980) and ''Un long cri dans la nuit: Cinq Années à l'Asile'' ("A Long Cry in the Night: Five Years in the Asylum", 1990). The last autobiography title comes from the song ''Un long cri dans la nuit'', written and composed for Lady Alys by the songwriter [[Christine Charbonneau]] in 1989.
Several of Robi's songs have been used for commercial ads. Sico, notably, played on the similarity between its [[brand name]] and the title of "Tico Tico" to produce a very catchy campaign based on a spoof of the song.
Robitaille died in the [[Hôpital Maisonneuve-Rosemont]], Montreal, at the age of 88, on May 28, 2011.
== Discography == * ''Diva'' (2005) (recorded in 1946 at the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]) * ''Laissez-moi encore chanter'' (1989)
Compilations : * ''Alys Robi, Collection QIM'' (2005) * ''Alys Robi, l'anthologie'' (2004) * ''La Collection – volume 1 & 2'' (1995) * ''La Collection – volume 1'' (1995) * ''Les Succès d'Alys Robi'' (1962, 1995)
==References== {{reflist}} *Official website: [http://www.ladyalysrobi.com www.ladyalysrobi.com]
==Further reading== * Beaunoyer, Jean. Fleur d'Alys. Montréal: Leméac, cop. 1994. 254, [4] p., ill. (ports.). {{ISBN|2-7609-5133-2}} * Sévigny, Jean-Pierre. ''Sierra Norteña: the Influence of Latin Music on the French-Canadian Popular Song and Dance Scene, Especially as Reflected in the Career of Alys Robi and the Pedagogy of Maurice Lacasse-Morenoff''. Montréal: Productions Juke-Box, 1994. 13 p. ''N.B''. Published text of a paper prepared for, and presented, on 12 March 1994, the conference, ''Popular Music Music & Identity'' (Montréal, Qué., 12–13 March 1994), under the auspices of the Canadian Branch of the International Association for the Study of Popular Music.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Robi, Alys}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian autobiographers]] [[Category:Canadian female jazz singers]] [[Category:French-language singers of Canada]] [[Category:French Quebecers]] [[Category:Musicians from Montreal]] [[Category:Musicians from Quebec City]] [[Category:RCA Victor artists]] [[Category:Lobotomised people]] [[Category:Spanish-language singers of Canada]] [[Category:Women autobiographers]] [[Category:20th-century Canadian singers]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]]

revision.text:
{{about|the American politician|the Canadian politician|50th New Brunswick Legislature}} {{Infobox State Senator | honorific-prefix = | name = Robert Lee "Bob" Hall | honorific-suffix = | image = TheHonorableBobHallHeadshot.jpg | caption= | state_senate = Texas | state = Texas | district = [[Texas Senate, District 2|2nd]] | term_start = January 13, 2015 | term_end = | preceded = [[Bob Deuell]] | succeeded = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1942|3|5}} | birth_place =[[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], [[Florida]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place= | nationality = [[United States|American]] | spouse =Sarah Kay Smith Hall | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | relations = | children =3 | residence =[[Edgewood, Texas|Edgewood]], [[Van Zandt County, Texas|Van Zandt County]]
[[Texas]] | alma_mater = [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]] | occupation =Businessman | profession = | signature = | website = | footnotes = |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = [[United States Air Force]] |serviceyears = 1964–1969 |rank = [[File:US-O3 insignia.svg|20px]] [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] |unit = Space and Missiles Systems Division }} '''Robert Lee Hall''', known as '''Bob Hall''' (born March 5, 1942), is an [[United States|American]] [[politician]] who is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] member of the [[Texas State Senate]]. Aligned with the [[Tea Party movement]], he succeeded fellow Republican [[Bob Deuell]], whom he unseated by three hundred votes in the Republican [[runoff election]] held on May 27, 2014. ==Early life and education== Hall graduated in 1960 with honors from [[George D. Chamberlain High School]] in [[Tampa, Florida]]. He is an [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]]. In 1964, Hall received a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[electrical engineering]] from [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]]. At The Citadel, he was cited in ''Who's Who in American Colleges and Universities''.{{cite web |url=http://votebobhall.com/About-Bob.html |title=More About Bob Hall |publisher=votebobhall.com |accessdate=November 27, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141109042151/http://votebobhall.com/About-Bob.html |archivedate=November 9, 2014 |df= }} Hall was a [[Captain (United States)|captain]] in the [[United States Air Force]]. From 1984 to 2013, he operated a business, Professional Proposal Management, Inc., which assisted companies in obtaining government contracts.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} ==Political career== Hall's run against incumbent State Senator [[Bob Deuell]] was his second run for public office. Hall had previously filed and campaigned for the same seat in 2012, but was subsequently disqualified due to failure to meet constitutional residency requirements.{{cite web|url=http://myrockwallnews.com/bob-hall/ |title=State Senate candidate Bob Hall disqualified by GOP from running against Deuell – The Rockwall News | The Rockwall News |publisher=Myrockwallnews.com |date= |accessdate=2017-12-22}} Hall received endorsements from various conservative individuals and organizations{{cite web|url=http://senatorbobhall.com/endorsements/ |title=Endorsements | Senator Bob Hall | Constitutional Conservative |publisher=Senator Bob Hall |date= |accessdate=2017-12-22}} including former Texas Republican State Chairman [[Cathie Adams]], who praised Hall's commitment.{{cite web|url=https://senatorbobhall.com/endorsements/|title=SenatorBobHall.com/Endorsements }} Hall unseated Deuell in a runoff election, 18,230 votes (50.4 percent) to 17,930 (49.6 percent).{{cite web|url=https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/may27_173_state.htm?x=0&y=2631&id=422|title=2014 Republican Party Primary Runoff: Election Night Returns|publisher=[[Texas Secretary of State]]|accessdate=May 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529052346/https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/may27_173_state.htm?x=0&y=2631&id=422|archivedate=May 29, 2014|df=}}Leszcynski, Ray. [http://trailblazersblog.dallasnews.com/2014/05/deuell-hall-hold-home-serve-in-tight-race.html/ Bob Hall ousts District 2 incumbent Deuell], ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'', May 27, 2014. Deuell had led a three-candidate field in the [[primary election|primary]] on March 4, with 23,847 votes (48.5 percent). Because he fell short of a [[majority]], he was placed in the runoff with the number-two candidate, Bob Hall, who in the primary polled 19,085 votes (38.8 percent). The remaining 6,240 votes (12.7 percent) went to a third candidate, Mark Thompson.{{cite web|url=https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar04_169_state.htm?x=0&y=8866&id=965 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140305183835/https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar04_169_state.htm?x=0&y=8866&id=965 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 5, 2014 |title=Republican primary election returns, March 4, 2014 (Senate District 10) |publisher=team1.sos.state.tx.us |accessdate=March 5, 2014 }} With his [[nomination]] in hand, Hall defeated [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] nominee, Don Bates, in the November 4 [[general election]]. In the 2018 Republican primary, Hall was challenged by state representative [[Cindy Burkett]], who ran as a politically moderate alternative to him. Hall defeated her in the March 6, 2018, primary election.{{cite web | last1=Leszcynski | first1=Ray | title=Sen. Bob Hall Wins District 2 Republican Primary, Beats Back Challenge from Four-Term Rep. Cindy Burkett | url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2018-elections/2018/03/06/sen-bob-hall-standing-ground-district-2-republican-primary-four-term-house-rep-cindy-burkett | date=March 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=April 27, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Formby | first1=Brandon | last2=Greene | first2=Sydney | title=GOP State Sen. Craig Estes Ousted; Sen. Bob Hall Defeats Burkett | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/03/06/craig-estes-angela-paxton-bob-hall-texas-senate-primary-2018/ | date=March 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=April 27, 2018}} ==Voting record and political positions== ===Education=== Hall consistently votes against unfunded mandates on local public schools. He supported numerous pieces of legislation regarding unfunded mandates in education including SB 1068, which amends Chapter 38.101 of the Education Code so that an assessment of the physical fitness of a student may only be done at the request of the student's parents,{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/85r/pdf/85RSJ03-06-F.PDF#page=18 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} and SB 1309, which removes all mandates for teacher training and student instruction on internet safety, teen dating violence, bullying, parenting and paternity, child abuse, and bus safety.{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/85r/pdf/85RSJ03-14-F.PDF#page=35 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} ===Abortion=== During his tenure as a Senator, Hall has consistently supported anti-abortion legislation. Examples of supported legislation by Hall include SB 10, which created stricter abortion requirements at Health Care Facilities;{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/85r/pdf/85RSJ05-08-F.PDF#page=39 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} SB 258, which authorizes burial or cremation of fetal tissue after abortion or miscarriage;{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/85r/pdf/85RSJ03-30-F.PDF#page=4 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} and SB 20, which prohibits coverage of abortion from taxpayer funded health insurance plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/85r/pdf/85RSJ03-27-F.PDF#page=8 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} ===Gun rights=== Hall has been described as a [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]] advocate, regularly voting against restrictions on gun ownership. He voted in favor of HB 910, which authorizes open carry of handguns;{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/84r/pdf/84RSJ05-29-F.PDF#page=241 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} SB 16, which reduces the fee for firearm carry licenses;{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.senate.state.tx.us/sjrnl/85r/pdf/85RSJ05-11-F.PDF#page=48 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} and SB 11, which authorizes concealed carry of firearms on college campuses.{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.house.state.tx.us/hjrnl/84r/pdf/84RDAY84CFINAL.PDF#page=25 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} ===Property tax=== Hall has voted on several pieces of property tax reform legislation. SB 1 would require cities and counties to hold an election if they plan to increase their property tax revenues by 6%, regardless of whether they are increasing the actual tax rate or just taking advantage of rising property values.{{cite web|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2017/08/02/house-considering-bevy-property-tax-legislation/ |title=House property tax ideas range from minor tweaks to ending school taxes |publisher=The Texas Tribune |date= |accessdate=2017-12-22}} Hall also voted for the 2015 budget bill, which put billions of dollars into property tax relief funds to buy down local property taxes for 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.journals.house.state.tx.us/hjrnl/84r/pdf/84RDAY83FINAL.PDF#page=344 |title=Senate Journal listing|website=www.journals.senate.state.tx.us|format=PDF}} == Legislative ratings == {{BLP unsourced section|date=December 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Hall legislative rankings by interest groups |- ! Year ! Texans for Fiscal Responsibility ! Texas Values Action "Family & Faith" ! Texas State Rifle Association ! Texas Right to Life |- |2017 | style="background: white" | 100 (A+) | 98 (A+) | style="background: white" | (A+) | 100 (A+) |} ==2018 reelection== Hall won his second state Senate term in the [[general election]] held on November 6, 2018. With 152,659 votes (59.4 percent), he defeated the Democrat Kendall Scudder, who finished with 104,528 (40.6 percent).{{cite web|url=https://enrpages.sos.state.tx.us/public/nov06_331_state.htm?x=0&y=0&id=545|title=Election Returns|date=November 6, 2018|publisher=Texas Secretary of State|accessdate=November 7, 2018}} ==Personal life== Hall and his wife, the former Sarah Kay Smith, a native of [[Commerce, Texas|Commerce]] in [[Hunt County, Texas|Hunt County]] in East Texas, live in Tailwind Airpark in [[Edgewood, Texas|Edgewood]], a community for pilots and aviation enthusiasts which has its own runway and hangars. The couple is [[Southern Baptist]] and has three adult sons.{{cite web|url=http://www.texasobserver.org/meet-bob-hall-tea-party-true-believer-headed-texas-senate/|title=Meet Bob Hall, the Tea Party True Believer Headed to the Senate|publisher="[[The Texas Observer]]''|date=May 30, 2014|accessdate=November 27, 2014}} ==Electoral history== {{Election box begin no party | title=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Primary, 2018: Senate District 2 }} {{Election box candidate no party with winner | winner = ✓ | candidate = Bob Hall | votes = 35,561 | percentage = 53.2 | change = }} {{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Bruce Hood | image = BruceHoodAtQEDcon2015-1.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Bruce Hood giving his Why We Fail to Reason & How to Speak Easily talk at QED 2015 | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date|df=y|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=y|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = British | nationality = British | fields = | workplaces = [[University of Bristol]], [[University of Cambridge]], [[University of Dundee]], [[Harvard University]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | alma_mater = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | thesis_url = http://search.lib.cam.ac.uk/?itemid=|manuscrpdb|9627 | thesis_title = Development of visual selective attention | thesis_year = 1991 | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | footnotes = | spouse = | website = {{URL|brucemhood.wordpress.com/}} }}
'''Bruce MacFarlane Hood''' is a Canadian-born British experimental [[psychology|psychologist]] who specialises in [[developmental cognitive neuroscience]]. He is currently based at the [[University of Bristol]] and his major research interests include the cognitive processes behind adult magical thinking.
==Biography== Hood's father was a journalist and of Scottish descent while his mother was an Australian.<ref name="GR">{{cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/2996545.Bruce_M_Hood|title=Bruce M. Hood|publisher=Goodreads}}</ref> He moved to [[Dundee]], [[Scotland]], at aged 8, and lived in Australia, New Zealand, and Canada during his childhood.<ref name="GR"/> He completed undergraduate studies in psychology, then received a Master of Arts and a [[Master of Philosophy]] from the [[University of Dundee]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Fisher | first1 = S. | last2 = Hood | first2 = B. | authorlink2 = Bruce Hood (psychologist)| doi = 10.1111/j.2044-8295.1987.tb02260.x | title = The stress of the transition to university: A longitudinal study of psychological disturbance, absent-mindedness and vulnerability to homesickness | journal = British Journal of Psychology | volume = 78 | issue = 4 | pages = 425 | year = 1987 }}</ref> He received a PhD from [[University of Cambridge]] in 1991, studying the visual development of infants.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://search.lib.cam.ac.uk/?itemid=%7Cmanuscrpdb%7C9627|title = Development of visual selective attention in the human infant|accessdate = 13 September 2014|website = LibrarySearch|publisher = University of Cambridge|last = Hood|first = Bruce MacFarlane}}</ref> After moving to the US he took a place as a visiting professor at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] and faculty professor at [[Harvard University]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Hood | first1 = B. M. | authorlink1 = Bruce Hood (psychologist)| last2 = Willen | first2 = J. D. | last3 = Driver | first3 = J. | doi = 10.1111/1467-9280.00024 | title = Adult's Eyes Trigger Shifts of Visual Attention in Human Infants | journal = Psychological Science | volume = 9 | issue = 2 | pages = 131 | year = 1998 }}</ref> He is currently a professor at the [[University of Bristol]], where he conducts research at the School of Experimental Psychology and teaches the Developmental Psychology modules.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://dbms.ilrt.bris.ac.uk/neuroscience/people/14588/|title = Professor Bruce Hood|accessdate = 6 September 2014|website = Bristol Neuroscience|publisher = University of Bristol}}</ref>
== Work ==
=== Cognitive development in childhood === In his research, Hood investigates various aspects of cognitive development in children. He is most known for looking at the origins of superstitious beliefs in children. Most notably, his research showed that children inherently prefer 'their' individual objects over duplicated ones,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Children prefer certain individuals over perfect duplicates|last = Hood|first = BM|date = January 2008|journal = Cognition|doi = 10.1016/j.cognition.2007.01.012|pmid = 17335793|volume=106|pages=455–62}}</ref> a behaviour which persists into adulthood.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Picasso Paintings, Moon Rocks, and Hand-Written Beatles Lyrics: Adults' Evaluations of Authentic Objects|last = Frazier|first = BN|date = January 2009|journal = Journal of Cognition and Culture|doi = 10.1163/156853709X414601|pmid = 20631919|volume=9|pages=1–14|pmc=2903069}}</ref>
Further, he investigates how children use the gaze to infer about the mental states of humans they are interacting with.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Children's use of the temporal dimension of gaze for inferring preference|last = Einav|first = S|date = January 2006|journal = Developmental Psychology|doi = 10.1037/0012-1649.42.1.142|pmid = 16420124|volume=42|pages=142–52}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Tell-tale eyes: children's attribution of gaze aversion as a lying cue|last = Einav|first = S|date = November 2008|journal = Developmental Psychology|doi = 10.1037/a0013299|pmid = 18999328|volume=44|pages=1655–67}}</ref> Hood also studies how children form theories, for example about gravity<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1467-7687.00013/abstract|title = Gravity does rule for falling events|last = Hood|first = Bruce M.|date = 4 January 2002|journal = Developmental Science|accessdate = 13 September 2014|doi = 10.1111/1467-7687.00013|volume=1|pages=59–63}}</ref> and spatial representations.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Children's search behaviour in large-scale space: developmental components of exploration.|last = Smith|first = AD|year = 2005|journal = Perception|doi = 10.1068/p5270|pmid = 16309116|volume=34|pages=1221–9}}</ref>
=== Public engagement === Hood has been engaging in science outreach since the beginning of his career. In 2006, he appeared on the [[BBC Radio 4]] show ''[[Material World (radio programme)|Material World]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2006/5073.html|title = Bruce Hood discusses superstition on Radio 4|date = 22 September 2006|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> and also presented his research at the [[British Science Association]] Science Festival later in the same year.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2006/5039.html|title = Born with a superstitious brain|date = 7 September 2006|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> Hood argues that humans evolved to "detect patterns in the world" and defines the supersense as the "inclination to infer that there are hidden forces that create the patterns that we think we detect".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pointofinquiry.org/bruce_m._hood_supersense_why_we_believe_in_the_unbelievable/|title=Bruce M. Hood – Supersense: Why We Believe in the Unbelievable|author=[[D. J. Grothe]]|publisher= [[Point of Inquiry]]|date=17 April 2009|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
He reappeared at the same event three years later in 2009<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2009/6520.html|title = British Science Festival talk explores supersense|date = 8 September 2009|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> and published his popular science book ''SuperSense: Why We Believe in the Unbelievable'' in the same year. The book tackles how the human brain generates superstitious beliefs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://neuronarrative.wordpress.com/2009/05/22/are-we-born-believers-or-cultural-receivers-a-discussion-with-author-and-psychologist-bruce-hood/|title = Are We Born Believers or Cultural Receivers? A Discussion with Author and Psychologist Bruce Hood|date = 22 May 2009|accessdate = 6 September 2014|website = Neuronarrative|publisher = WordPress.com|last = DiSalvo|first = David}}</ref>
In 2011, Hood appeared on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[The Infinite Monkey Cage]]'' show to talk about the science of superstition<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2011/7713.html|title = Bruce Hood on BBC Radio 4's The Infinite Monkey Cage|date = 4 July 2011|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/podcasts/series/timc/all|title = Mon 04 July 11: Science and the supernatural|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = The Infinite Monkey Cage|publisher = BBC}}</ref> and also participated in the live performance event ''Uncaged Monkeys'' in Bristol.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2010/7616.html|title = Uncaged Monkeys at the Colston Hall|date = 12 May 2011|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> Later the same year, he held the prestigious [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]] titled 'Meet Your Brain'.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://richannel.org/christmas-lectures/2011/meet-your-brain |title=Christmas Lectures 2011 – Meet your Brain : Ri Channel |work=Ri Channel |accessdate=29 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2011/8127.html|title = Bristol psychologist gives 2011 Royal Institution's Christmas Lectures|date = 20 December 2011|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> Organized in three parts, they explored the structure of the brain, how the brain controls behaviours and thoughts and how brains allow humans to function in a social context.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2011/dec/26/science-weekly-podcast-christmas-lectures|title = Science Weekly podcast: Bruce Hood has Christmas lectures on the brain|date = 26 December 2011|accessdate = 13 September 2013|website = Science Weekly|last = Jha|first = Alok}}</ref>
In 2012, Hood published his second popular science book ''The Self Illusion: Why there is no 'you' inside your head'' (published under the alternative title ''The Self Illusion: How the social brain creates identity'' in America). In this book, he argues that the human sense of self is a construct of the brain which facilitates experiencing and interacting with the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.wired.com/2012/05/the-self-illusion-an-interview-with-bruce-hood/|title = The Self Illusion: An Interview With Bruce Hood|date = 25 May 2012|accessdate = 13 September 2014|work = Wired|last = Lehrer|first = Jonah|authorlink = Jonah Lehrer}}</ref> "Who we are," Hood writes, "is a story of our self − a constructed narrative that our brain creates".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hood|first1=Bruce|title=The Self Illusion|date=2012|publisher=Constable|location=London|isbn=978-1-78033-007-5|page=xi}}</ref> Bruce uses a "a distinction that William James drew between the self as "I" and "me." Our consciousness of the self in the here and now is the "I" and most of the time, we experience this as being an integrated and coherent individual – a bit like the character in the story. The self which we tell others about, is autobiographical or the "me" which again is a coherent account of who we think we are based on past experiences, current events and aspirations for the future."<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.wired.com/2012/05/the-self-illusion-an-interview-with-bruce-hood/|title = The Self Illusion: An Interview With Bruce Hood|date = 25 May 2012|accessdate = 3 February 2016|work = Wired|last = Lehrer|first = Jonah|authorlink = Jonah Lehrer}}</ref>
In October 2012, Hood devised the world's largest simultaneous memory experiment for the [[Society of Biology]] involving 2000 participants to demonstrate the phenomenon of false memories.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2012/8872.html|title = Bristol professor designs game for Guinness World Record attempt|date = 19 October 2011|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> This was officially recognised by the [[Guinness Book of Records]] in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.societyofbiology.org/news/news-archive/14-news/477-society-of-biology-sets-new-world-record|title = Society of Biology sets new World Record|date = 11 June 2013|accessdate = 6 September 2014|website = Society of Biology|publisher = The Society of Biology}}</ref>
Hood's third popular science book, ''The Domesticated Brain'', was published in 2014 and explores the neuro-cognitive origins and consequences of social behaviour in humans. The book's thesis is that "over the most recent evolution, the last 20,000 years", humans have been "selecting each other for prosocial behaviour and that has changed our brains and the way we've become more codependent".<ref name=skepticuleinterview>{{cite web|url=http://www.skepticule.co.uk/2015/05/skepticule-094-20150425.html|title=''Skepticule 094: Question.Explore.Discover – QEDcon 2015, Manchester, UK – Special Episode 1 of 2 (inc. interview with Bruce Hood)''|author1=Paul Thompson|author2=Paul S. Jenkins|author3=Paul Orton|publisher= Skepticule|date=25 April 2015|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> He presented this topic at [[The Royal Society of Arts]],<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thersa.org/events/audio-and-past-events/2014/Bruce-Hood-on-the-Domesticated-Brain|title = Bruce Hood on the Domesticated Brain|date = 7 May 2014|accessdate = 17 September 2014|website = RSA Events|publisher = RSA}}</ref> [[The Royal Society]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bristol.ac.uk/pace/public-events/bruce-hood.html|title = Royal Society talk – Professor Bruce Hood|date = 29 May 2014|accessdate = 13 September 2014|website = Bristol University Public and Ceremonial Events Office|publisher = University of Bristol}}</ref> and the 2014 [[Cheltenham Science Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cheltenhamfestivals.com/science/whats-on/2014/bruce-hood-the-domesticated-brain/|title = Bruce Hood: The domesticated brain|accessdate = 13 September 2014|website = The Times Cheltenham Festivals Science '14|publisher = Cheltenham Festivals}}</ref>
=== Skepticism === [[File:Prof Bruce Hood talking at QED 2011 3.jpg|thumb|Professor Bruce Hood at the QED conference in Manchester 2011]] Hood played a key part in exposing the [[ADE 651]] bogus bomb detector and similar devices in January 2010. He got involved in exposing the scam upon realising that the devices were produced locally in Somerset (UK) and challenged the creator of the devices, Jim McCormick, to demonstrate their validity. Even though McCormick initially agreed to this, the demonstration was then delayed and McCormick later required Hood to sign a non-disclosure statement concerning their meeting. Hood had also contacted the [[BBC]] about McCormick and his fraudulent products, which ultimately resulted in the production of a [[BBC Newsnight]] documentary about [[ADE 651]] and a related device, the [[GT200]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/8471187.stm|title = Export ban for useless 'bomb detector'|date = 22 January 2010|accessdate = 6 September 2014|publisher = BBC Newsnight|last = Hawley|first = Caroline|last2 = Jones|first2 = Meirion}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/8520303.stm|title = Why did UK not ban so-called 'bomb detectors' earlier?|date = 17 February 2010|accessdate = 21 September 2014|publisher = BBC Newsnight|last = Jones|first = Meirion|last2 = Hawley|first2 = Caroline}}</ref> In this documentary, Hood demonstrates that the perceived effect of the devices can be explained by the [[ideomotor phenomenon]], which had fooled naive users.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/interview_with_bruce_m._hood/|title = Interview with Bruce M. Hood|date = 5 March 2010|accessdate = 6 September 2014|website = The Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|publisher = Center for Inquiry|last = Sturgess|first = Kylie|authorlink = Kylie Sturgess}}</ref>
Contrary to prominent skeptics such as [[Richard Dawkins]], Hood is convinced that superstitious beliefs are inevitable and even beneficial to humans. For instance, he argues that [[essentialism]] is beneficial to social interactions, since it allows humans to overcome objectification and attribute uniqueness to other humans. However, Hood clearly differentiates between secular and religious beliefs, where secular supernatural beliefs are universally applicable across cultures and religious beliefs are culturally specific. He also argues that secular superstitious beliefs do predispose humans to religious beliefs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.forgoodreason.org/bruce_hood_why_we_believe_in_the_unbelievable|title = Why we believe in the unbelievable|date = 28 March 2010|accessdate = 8 September 2014|website = For Good Reason|publisher = For Good Reason|last = Grothe|first = DJ|authorlink = DJ Grothe}}</ref>
===Speakezee===
In 2015 Hood founded Speakezee,<ref name=speakezeeabout>{{cite web|url=https://www.speakezee.org/about |title=About Speakezee |publisher=Speakezee |year=2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015 }}</ref> an academic speaking platform which can be used by institutions and organisations to find speakers for their events and [[vice versa]].
"I got the idea after being invited to give too many talks than I could possibly accept, so this system should make it easier to find others who are just as good".<ref name="speakezeeblog" />
Speakers are able to create profiles detailing their subject expertise and speaking experience. Organisers are then able to find and short list speakers and contact them directly to discuss speaking at their event.<ref name=speakezeeabout/> It also allows academics to advertise their specialist talks to other academics who organise departmental seminars.<ref name="bathuni">{{cite web|url=http://www.bath.ac.uk/marketing/public-engagement/get-involved/opportunities/speakezee.html |title=Register to 'Speakezee', a new online speakers bureau|publisher=[[University of Bath]]|date=8 April 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015 }}</ref>
"At its heart is the desire to help more academics engage with the public and to make it easier for organisers to find relevant experts to talk at their event, whatever the size."<ref name=speakezeeabout/>
A platform that is free to use, Speakezee is currently in its first phase and primarily focused in the UK. More functionality and new features are planned for the future, making it more useful for a wider audience and with a view to ultimately expanding the site's use internationally.<ref name=speakezeeabout/><ref name="speakezeeblog">{{cite web|url=https://brucemhood.wordpress.com/2015/02/17/speakezee-org/ |title=Speakezee.Org|author=Bruce Hood |date=17 February 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015 }}</ref> Hood hopes "it will stimulate a café culture of intellectual exchange".<ref name=skepticuleinterview/>
== Awards and recognition == He was awarded a [[Sloan Fellowship]] in neuroscience in 1997,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sloan.org/fellowships/past-fellows/?L=0252F&tx_sloangrants_sloanfellows%5Bpage%5D=&tx_sloangrants_sloanfellows%5BlastPage%5D=0&tx_sloangrants_sloanfellows%5Bsortby%5D=5&tx_sloangrants_sloanfellows%5Border%5D=1&tx_sloangrants_sloanfellows%5Bsearch%5D=hood&tx_sloangrants_sloanfellows%5Bcontroller%5D=Fellows&cHash=9bb01910a06741610f6481c71b2eba97|title = Past fellows|accessdate = 6 September 2014|website = Alfred P. Sloan Foundation|publisher = Alfred P. Sloan Foundation}}</ref> a Young Investigator Award from the International Society for Infant Studies and the [[Robert L. Fantz]] prize in 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.apa.org/apf/funding/fantz.aspx|title = Robert L. Fantz Memorial Award for Young Psychologists|accessdate = 6 September 2014|publisher=American Psychological Foundation}}</ref> He was also elected to fellow status by the [[American Psychological Association]] and is a fellow of The Society for Biology and [[The Royal Institution]] of Great Britain.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thersa.org/events/speakers-archive/h/professor-bruce-hood|title = Professor Bruce Hood|accessdate = 13 September 2014|website = RSA|publisher = RSA}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://brucemhood.wordpress.com/about/|title = About Bruce|accessdate = 6 September 2014|website = Professor Bruce M. Hood – A blog where science and superstition meet|publisher = WordPress.com}}</ref>
He won the 2011/12 University of Bristol individual engagement award, specifically for his local science engagement activity with the group [[At-Bristol]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2012/8533.html|title = 2011/12 Engagement Award winners announced|date = 28 May 2012|accessdate = 7 September 2014|website = Bristol University News|publisher = Bristol University}}</ref> In 2013, Hood received the Public Engagement and Media Awards from [[The British Psychological Society]] for his commitment to public engagement through public lectures, media appearances, pub events and science festivals.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.bps.org.uk/news/professor-bruce-hood-receives-bps-award|title = Professor Bruce Hood receives BPS award|date = 30 January 2014|accessdate = 4 September 2014|website = The British Psychological Society|publisher = The British Psychological Society|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006113611/http://www.bps.org.uk/news/professor-bruce-hood-receives-bps-award|archivedate = 6 October 2014|df = }}</ref>

'''Carlo Zinelli''' (July 2, 1916 – January 27, 1974) was an [[outsider art]]ist who suffered from [[schizophrenia]].
He was born in the [[Italy|Italian]] countryside near [[Verona, Italy|Verona]] but left for the city in 1934. He volunteered for the [[Spanish Civil War]] in 1939, but his schizophrenia quickly revealed itself, and he was placed on medical leave after only two months. He was committed to the [[psychiatric hospital]] in Verona in 1947 and spent ten years in almost total isolation.<ref name="Wojcik">{{cite book |last=Wojcik |first=Daniel |title=Outsider Art: Visionary Worlds and Trauma |publisher=[[University Press of Mississippi]] |year=2016 |isbn=978-1-4968-0808-0}}</ref>
Carlo's life took a turn ten years later, when he and twenty other patients were admitted to the painting [[studio|atelier]] created by [[sculpture|sculptors]] Michael Noble and Pino Castagna and [[psychiatrist]] Mario Marini. In this atelier, patients were encouraged to paint or sculpt freely.
Completely engrossed by his work, Carlo drew for eight hours a day with tempera paints and colored pencils. This routine seems to have calmed him considerably; clinical evaluations from this time comment on his good behavior. By 1964, his work had been exhibited, and he had attracted the attention of art historians associated with [[Jean Dubuffet]] and the [[Compagnie de l'Art Brut]].<ref name= "folkart">{{cite news |last=Gomez |first=Edward M. |url= https://hyperallergic.com/367669/in-carlo-zinelli-and-eugen-gabritschevskys-art-the-life-spirit-endures/ |title=In Carlo Zinelli and Eugen Gabritschevsky’s Art, the Life Spirit Endures |work=[[Hyperallergic]] |date=March 25, 2017 |accessdate=June 24, 2017}}</ref>
In 1969, the hospital moved to a new location in Marzana, Italy. Disoriented by the move, Carlo painted much more infrequently until his death in 1974.
His body of work comprises about nineteen hundred paintings and a few sculptures. The paintings are created on white sheets, and are two-sided from 1962 to 1968. These two-sided works can be seen as continuous, as a single narrative from one side to the other.
He used pure colors to create narratives that tell the story of his childhood in the country, frequently repeating figures to cover the entire background in "horror vacui" style. His human figures are always solid shapes drawn in profile, often with holes to represent eyes or other features.
