revision.text:
{{about|the end-times theorist|the member of the [[Kentucky House of Representatives]]|David Meade}} {{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{infobox person | name = David Meade | other_names = <!--use this for pen name if/when real name is revealed--> | image = | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_place = United States | occupation = self-described "Christian numerologist",<ref name=Guarino/> author, researcher, investigative journalist, and forensic investigator | alma_mater = [[University of Louisville]]<ref name=washingtonpost>{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Kristine|title=The man whose biblical doomsday claim has some nervously eyeing Sept. 23|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2017/09/20/the-christian-numerologist-whose-biblical-doomsday-claim-has-some-nervously-eyeing-sept-23/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[Jeff Bezos|Nash Holdings LLC]]|date=20 September 2017}}</ref> | known_for = [[Nibiru cataclysm#2017 Revival|Nibiru]], doomsday predictions | education = [[Astronomy]]{{efn|text=This claim is unverifiable, since "David Meade" is a pen name and the author in question has not revealed his real name.<ref name=washingtonpost/>}} | nationality = American | website = [http://writers-web-services.com Planet X – Omega Project], [http://planetxnews.com/meade/ David Meade Planet X News] | footnotes = The author is known only by his pen name and some information is unverifiable since he has not chosen to reveal his true identity.<ref name=washingtonpost/> }}
'''David Meade''' is the pen name of an American [[End time|end-times]] [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorist]] and book author who has yet to disclose his real name. Meade, who describes himself as a "Christian numerologist",<ref name=Guarino>{{cite news|last1=Guarino|first1=Ben|title=Will the mysterious shadow planet Nibiru obliterate Earth in October? No.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/01/05/will-the-mysterious-shadow-planet-nibiru-obliterate-earth-in-october-no/|newspaper=The Washington Post|publisher=Nash Holdings LLC|date=7 January 2017}}</ref> claims to have attended the [[University of Louisville]], where he "studied astronomy, among other subjects",<ref name=washingtonpost/><ref name=glum>{{cite web|last1=Glum|first1=Julia|title=Who Is David Meade? The World Is Ending Saturday, According to This Catholic-Raised Blogger|url=http://www.newsweek.com/end-world-david-meade-668820|periodical=[[Newsweek]]|publisher=[[Newsweek Media Group]]|date=22 September 2017}}</ref> but, because his real name is unknown, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that the university could not confirm whether he had ever been a student there.<ref name=washingtonpost/> He is also a writer, researcher and investigator who has written and self-published at least 13 books.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Doomsday writer David Meade: Who is he?|url=http://www.foxnews.com/science/2017/09/22/doomsday-writer-david-meade-who-is.html|work=[[Fox News]]|date=22 September 2017}}</ref><ref name=washingtonpost/> He made appearances and interviews on ''[[Coast to Coast AM]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[Glenn Beck Program]]'', [[YouTube]] with pastor Paul Begley, and the ''[[Daily Express]]''. He is best known for making numerous predictions, which have passed, regarding the end times, including that a hidden planet named [[Nibiru cataclysm|Nibiru]] (sometimes known as Planet X) would destroy the [[Earth]].
Meade predicted that planet Nibiru would collide with Earth on September 23, 2017, destroying it.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Karangu|first1=Jessie|title=The world is ending on September 23, according to a biblical prophecy|url=http://wjla.com/news/offbeat/the-world-is-ending-on-september-23-according-to-a-biblical-prophecy|website=[[WJLA-TV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=20 September 2017}}</ref> After his prediction failed, he revised the apocalypse to October, where he stated that the seven-year [[Great Tribulation|tribulation]] would possibly start followed by a [[Millennialism|millennium]] of peace.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Gajanan|first1=Mahita|title=David Meade Said the World Was Going to End Last Weekend. Now He Says It's Really Happening in October|quote=Meade, David: It is possible at the end of October we may be about to enter into the 7-year Tribulation period, to be followed by a Millennium of peace.|url=http://time.com/4955640/doomsday-world-end-david-meade/|periodical=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> In 2018, Meade again made several predictions for that year, for instance, that [[North Korea]] becoming a superpower in March 2018 and that Nibiru would destroy the Earth in spring.<ref name="International Business Times"/> Meade announced that the apocalypse would begin in March 2018, but he didn't predict the exact date.<ref name=Ibtimes/> After March 2018 passed, he moved the apocalypse to April 23, 2018, in which he also predicted the [[Sun]], [[Moon]], [[Jupiter]], and [[Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]] will signal the rapture, and that Nibiru would destroy the Earth that day.<ref name=Nzherald/> However, before that date he said that reports that he predicted the end on 23 April were "fake news", but that the rapture—but not the end of the world—would take place on an unspecified date between May and December 2018.
Meade is best known for using [[Bible]] passages and Bible verses regarding his predictions. His September 23 prediction was based on secret codes in the [[Giza pyramid complex|Giza Pyramids]] in [[Egypt]] and revolved around the [[Woman of the Apocalypse]]. He used the number [[33 (number)|33]] for his September 23 prediction, stating that “[[Jesus]] lived for 33 years” and that “[[Elohim#Canaanite religion|Elohim]] is mentioned 33 times in the Bible.” His October 2017 predictions were described on his website Planet X News and his book ''Will Planet X Signal the Rapture?''. His April 23 prediction was based on 12:1-2 in the [[Book of Revelation]] and referred to the woman as [[Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]] and stated the alignment represents "the Lion of the tribe of Judah".
== Early life == Meade was raised as a [[Catholic]]<ref name=glum/> and attended the [[University of Louisville]], where he claims to have studied astronomy and other subjects.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Staff|title=Kentucky man says 'end of days' is near|url=http://foxlexington.com/news/local/kentucky-man-says-end-of-days-is-near|website=[[WDKY-TV]]|publisher=Sinclair Broadcast Group|date=22 September 2017}}</ref> He also claims to have earned a master's degree in statistics.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Poulin|first1=Stepha|title=Facing the world's fake end|quote=master's degree in statistics|url=https://www.bgfalconmedia.com/forum/facing-the-world-s-fake-end/article_94b38e2a-a192-11e7-a91d-7f8a8c0b52c6.html|website=BG Falcon Media|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> According to his profile page on his website, he has worked for both the [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]] and private industry. He additionally stated that he has written investigative reports on abnormal state administration and executives for [[Fortune 1000]] organizations. It is not known which companies he worked for.<ref name=lyons>{{cite web|last1=Lyons|first1=Joseph|title=What Does David Meade Do? The Evangelical's Doomsday Theory Has Made Waves|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/what-does-david-meade-do-the-evangelicals-doomsday-theory-has-made-waves-2374639|website=[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]]|publisher=Bustle Digital Group|date=18 September 2017}}</ref> On his [[Google+|Google Plus]] page, he also claims to be an investigative journalist.<ref name=glum/>
In a September 2017 ''[[The Washington Post]]'' article, Meade said that he studied astronomy and that he attended a university in [[Kentucky]] but declined to say which campus he attended due to safety concerns.<ref name=washingtonpost/> He additionally refused to answer questions concerning which Fortune 1000 organizations he worked for and what he does for a living.<ref name=washingtonpost/> When he was asked where he lives, he claimed that he lives in "the heart of a major disaster" zone of [[Hurricane Irma]], but did not specify the state or city.<ref name=washingtonpost/>
Meade appeared on ''[[Coast to Coast AM]]'' with [[George Noory]] in January 2017 and was interviewed by the [[United States|American]] national television and radio program ''[[Glenn Beck Program]]'' in September 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Noory|first1=George|last2=Meade|first2=David|title=David Meade on Coast to Coast AM|url=https://www.coasttocoastam.com/guest/meade-david/84190|website=[[Coast to Coast AM]]|date=21 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="Glenn Beck">{{cite web|last1=Beck|first1=Glenn|last2=Meade|first2=David|title=9/21/17 – Planet X and the end of the age (w/ David Meade)|work=[[Glenn Beck]]|url=http://www.glennbeck.com/content/audio/92117-planet-x-and-the-end-of-the-age-w-david-meade/|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> In addition to books about Planet X, he has written books related to politics, such as ''The Coming Clinton Economic Collapse'' (2016) and ''The Coup D'état Against President Donald J. Trump'' (2017) .<ref name=washingtonpost/><ref name=lyons/><ref name=glum/>
== Predictions == {{see also|Nibiru cataclysm|Revelation 12 sign prophecy}} Meade received extensive media attention following his predictions that Nibiru would destroy Earth on September 23, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Molloy|first1=Mark|title=Nibiru: How the nonsense Planet X Armageddon and Nasa fake news theories spread globally|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/21/nibiru-nonsense-planet-x-armageddon-nasa-fake-news-theories/|date=24 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Is the world really about to come to an end? No, almost certainly not|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/world-end-apocalypse-locusts-swarm-eclipse-unilad-daily-star-planet-x-nibiru-a7868766.html|date=22 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Mack|first1=Eric|title=The End Of The World Is Coming, But Not From Nibiru On September 23|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericmack/2017/09/22/nibiru-planet-x-earth-2017-youtube-nasa/#a10b53c3054f|periodical=[[Forbes]]|publisher=Forbes, LLC|date=22 September 2017}}</ref> He first predicted Nibiru would hit the Earth in October 2017,<ref name=Guarino/> but moved it forward to September 23. On September 21,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Schwebke|first=Simon |title=End-of-world prediction interrupts TV broadcasts in Orange County|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2017/09/21/end-of-world-prediction-interrupts-tv-broadcasts-in-orange-county/|work=[[Orange County Register]]|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> an [[Orange County, California]] television station accidentally displayed his prediction in an emergency alert, and broadcasting officials stated that the false alert was caused by a glitch from a test by the [[Emergency Alert System]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Frauenfelder|first1=Mark|title=California TV warned viewers of David Meade prediction|url=https://boingboing.net/2017/09/22/emergency-broadcast-alert-warn.html|website=[[Boing Boing]]|date=22 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Fausto|first1=Alma|last2=Schwebke|first2=Scott|title=End-of-world message on TV was just glitch from a test of the Emergency Alert System|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2017/09/22/end-of-world-prediction-heard-on-o-c-television-channels-linked-to-equipment-failure/|newspaper=[[Orange County Register]]|publisher=[[Digital First Media]]|date=22 September 2017}}</ref> On September 21, he claimed in a [[Glenn Beck]] interview to have seen Nibiru from his house and that other people would see the sign as well.<ref name="Glenn Beck"/> Meade then changed his mind and stated that Nibiru would not collide with Earth on September 23.<ref>{{cite news|last1=May|first1=Ashley|title=Man who said world was ending Saturday changed his mind|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/09/22/man-who-said-world-ending-saturday-said-isnt-actually-ending/692907001/|quote=Meade, David: The world is not ending, but the world as we know it is ending. A major part of the world will not be the same the beginning of October.|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|date=22 September 2017}}</ref>
=== October 2017 predictions === As September 23 passed, however, Meade again revised the apocalypse to October, making new predictions for that month, such as Nibiru eclipsing the sun on October 5 and that several people would [[levitate]] into the sky (including current [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Donald Trump]] and [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]]) followed by a nuclear attack by [[North Korea]], [[China]], and [[Russia]] on the United States.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meade|first1=David|title=Will Planet X Signal the Rapture?|url=https://www.ebookit.com/tools/pd/Bo/eBookIt/booktitle-Will-Planet-X-Signal-the-Rapture|quote=Meade, David: I know the day but I'd rather not mention it at this point, but it is in October and in the very latter part) that Russia, China and North Korea would use a combination of drone submarines and unmarked container ships to engage in a nuclear attack on the US coast.|publisher=Self-published|website=ebookit.com}}</ref><ref name=PlanetXNews/> He predicted other events for that month, such as a series of magnitude 9.8 earthquakes; that the Earth's pole would shift by 30 degrees; that the United States would be split in half; and that [[Barack Obama]] would be elected as U.S. President for an [[Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution|illegal]] third term.<ref name=PlanetXNews>{{cite web|last1=Meade|first1=David|title=October 2017 and the 'End of Days'|url=http://planetxnews.com/2017/08/30/october-2017-end-days/|quote=Meade, David: Over one billion people will disappear. Among those who disappear will be President Trump and Vice President Pence. Obama will win the election. That should tell you something right there.|publisher=Self-published|date=30 August 2017}}</ref><!-- referring to the author's own material because he questioned summaries in other articles as inaccurate --> He also predicted that the 7-year [[Great Tribulation]] would start on October 15 and stated "[t]hat's when the action starts",<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Knudson|first1=Annalise|title=Will end of the world begin on Sunday, Oct. 15?|quote=Meade, David: That's when the action starts|url=http://www.silive.com/news/2017/10/post_1763.html|newspaper=[[Staten Island Advance]]|publisher=[[Advance Publications]]|date=1 October 2017}}</ref> but the month passed, and his predictions were incorrectly predicted.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Trim|first1=Liam|title=Sunday, October 15 will mark the start of Apocalypse if author David Meade is correct|url=http://www.somersetlive.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/planet-x-theory-sunday-october-629034|work=[[Western Gazette]]|date=11 October 2017}}</ref> His October 2017 predictions were described in his book ''Will Planet X Signal the Rapture?''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meade|first1=David|title=Will Planet X Signal the Rapture|url=https://www.amazon.com/Will-Planet-X-Signal-Rapture-ebook/dp/B01AL6X6DU|quote=Meade, David: My inspiration for this book was a vision that I'm aware of where it was revealed that in October of 2017|publisher=Self-published|website=[[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]|date=13 January 2016}}</ref>
=== Predictions for 2018 === In an interview with [[YouTube]] pastor Paul Begley, Meade made several predictions for 2018, such as North Korea becoming a world-class superpower in March 2018 and predicting that Nibiru would destroy the Earth in spring.<ref name="International Business Times">{{cite web|last=Jha |first=Nupur |title=Nibiru will hit Earth and cause doomsday in 2018, predicts David Meade|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nibiru-will-hit-earth-cause-doomsday-2018-predicts-david-meade-760172|website=International Business Times|quote=Meade, David:”Here's what I believe is going to start in the Spring of 2018: I believe North Korea will ascend to become a world-class superpower in March of 2018. I believe the great tribulation will begin after a short period of peace|date=11 February 2018}}</ref> In an article published by ''[[International Business Times]]'' on February 15, 2018, Meade announced that the apocalypse would begin in March 2018, but no date was given.<ref name=Ibtimes>{{Cite web|last1=Narayanan|first1=Nirmal|title=Sept 23 last year? No, Oct 15! Now it's March 2018, says conspiracy theorist David Meade on Nibiru apocalypse|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/sept-23-last-year-no-oct-15-now-its-march-2018-says-conspiracy-theorist-david-meade-nibiru-24506|work=International Business Times|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> He stated that several events in 2018, such as the [[January 2018 lunar eclipse|January 2018 super blue blood moon eclipse]], the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], and [[Israel]]'s 70-year celebration of independence, were signs of the apocalypse.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Narayanan|first1=Nirmal|title=Is Super Blue Red Moon a sign of inevitable apocalypse? Conspiracy theorists say yes|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/super-blue-red-moon-sign-inevitable-apocalypse-conspiracy-theorists-say-yes-23361|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Paez|first1=Danny|title=No, the Super Blue Blood Moon Isn't a Sign of the Apocalypse|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/40648-super-blue-blood-moon-isn-t-a-sign-of-the-apocalypse|website=[[Inverse (website)|Inverse]]|date=29 January 2018}}</ref> He called several officials in the United Nations "crazy people" after voting against the United States' decision to [[United States recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel|recognize]] [[Jerusalem]] as the capital of Israel, and his prediction came just 42 days before the blood moon eclipse.<ref name="International Business Times"/>
After March 2018 passed, he changed the apocalypse prediction to April 23, 2018, in which he also predicted the [[Sun]], [[Moon]], [[Jupiter]], and Virgo will signal the [[rapture]], and that Nibiru would destroy the Earth that day.<ref name=Nzherald>{{Cite web|last1=MacDonald|first1=Cheyenne|title=Conspiracy theorists claim end of world is coming April 23 when Nibiru appears|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=12031291|website=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=12 April 2018}}</ref> He referred to his prediction as "end of days convergence" and that the "disappearance of the Church will occur".<ref name=Nzherald/> Meade became the first preacher since [[William Miller (preacher)|William Miller]] to predict that the world would end on 23 April.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Pappas|first1=Stephanie|title=Wait For It...The First 'April 23rd Doomsday' Was Predicted in 1843|url=https://www.livescience.com/62293-bogus-doomsday-april-23.html|publisher=[[Live Science]]|date=12 April 2018}}</ref> On April 19, 2018, he stated that reports saying that he predicted the world would be destroyed on 23 April were "fake news", but that the rapture—but not the end of the world—would take place on an unspecified date between May and December 2018. He stated that the rapture would bring in seven years of “tribulation”, followed by 1,000 years of “peace and prosperity”, before the world is destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|title=No, the world will not end on Monday, says conspiracy theorist cited in reports |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/apr/19/david-meade-end-of-world-predictions-rapture |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=19 April 2018 |author= Adam Gabbatt|accessdate= 19 April 2018}}</ref> April 23, 2018 passed without incident and Meade's prediction of a rapture taking place has been labeled by some naysayers as one of the latest “kooky” doomsday calls.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Bryner|first1=Jeanna|title=The 'End of the World' Is Today. Here's Why We're Still Here|url=https://www.livescience.com/62378-doomsday-april-23.html|website=[[Live Science]]|date=23 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last1=Llorente|first1=Elizabeth|title=Rapture prediction for April 23 just latest of kooky doomsday calls|url=http://zlotonews.com/rapture-prediction-for-april-23-just-latest-of-kooky-doomsday-calls-3/|publisher=Zloto News|date=23 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Other predictions === Meade has made similar predictions in 2015 in his book ''Rapture 2015 and Planet X''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meade|first1=David|title=Rapture 2015 and Planet X|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Rapture_2015_and_Planet_X.html?id=hk8xBwAAQBAJ|website=[[Google Books]]|publisher=Self-published}}</ref> and in his 2013 book ''Comet Ison and the Return of Jesus'', in which he stated that [[Comet Ison]] is the biblical star [[Wormwood (Bible)|Wormwood]] and that it ties to Nibiru.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Meade|first1=David|title=Comet Ison – The Comet of the Millennium|url=https://www.business2community.com/oddball/comet-ison-comet-millennium-0646992|quote=Meade, David: The name of one of the Russian discoverers of this 3 to 4 mile wide comet with a 200,000 mile tail translates to WORMWOOD.|work=[[Business 2 Community]]|date=15 October 2013}}</ref> In September 2017, he also made predictions that North Korea would launch a nuclear attack against [[Yellowstone Caldera]] from a used Russian submarine parked off the [[California Coast Ranges|coast of California]], and that the attack would trigger a [[supervolcano]] eruption.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Seaburn|first1=Paul |title=North Korea, Yellowstone and Nukes Triggering Supervolcanoes|url=http://mysteriousuniverse.org/2017/11/north-korea-yellowstone-and-nukes-triggering-supervolcanoes/|work=Mysterious Universe|quote=Meade, David: A major eruption at Yellowstone would immediately end America’s status as a superpower in one single hour. Let’s look at the facts about the North Korean testing program. First, it’s apparent they have developed a hydrogen bomb. They are currently testing to determine exactly what yield of nuclear weapon will be necessary to disrupt the rock cap over the Yellowstone Caldera. In concert with foreign volcanic experts, they have been studying Mount Paektu for years. Because I knew too much and was on the threshold of revealing their battle order against the U.S., my webmaster account was decrypted at a very high level and I was sent threatening information. That’s all I can say for now. But I know the attack was from the East and not the West. Therefore, an Eastern dictatorship–likely North Korea itself.|date=14 November 2017}}</ref> He believed that there would be flooding similar to the [[Genesis flood narrative]] and that only believers would survive.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mehta |first=Anita |title=Doomsday prediction: Conspiracy theorist David Meade claims flooding like Noah's Ark will destroy Earth|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/doomsday-prediction-conspiracy-theorist-david-meade-claims-flooding-like-noahs-ark-will-destroy-753296|website=[[International Business Times]]|date=15 December 2017}}</ref> He also believed that Russia would be able to wipe the United States out in less than 30 minutes if a war broke out between the [[Russia–United States relations|two]] countries.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Narayanan|first1=Nirmal |title=Russia could wipe out US in less than 30 minutes, says Nibiru theorist David Meade|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/russia-could-wipe-out-us-less-30-minutes-says-nibiru-theorist-david-meade-26186|website=[[International Business Times]]|date=5 May 2018}}</ref>
== Reactions == Meade has faced criticism from fellow Christians: [[Ed Stetzer]], writing for ''[[Christianity Today]]'', stated that "there is no such thing as a 'Christian numerologist{{' "}},<ref name=Stetzer/> and described Meade as "a made-up expert in a made-up field talking about a made-up event."<ref name=Stetzer>{{cite web|last1=Stetzer|first1=Ed|title=No, the World Won't End Next Week and There's No Such Thing as a Christian Numerologist|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/edstetzer/2017/september/end-times-fake-news.html|periodical=[[Christianity Today]]|date=16 September 2017}}</ref> Christopher M. Graney, a professor with the [[Vatican Observatory]] Foundation, noted that the supposedly unique astronomical event cited by Meade as a harbinger of doom was, in fact, quite common, having occurred four times in the last millennium.<ref name=graney>{{cite web|last1=Graney|first1=Christopher|title=Biblical Signs in the Sky? September 23, 2017|url=http://www.vofoundation.org/blog/biblical-signs-sky-september-23-2017/|publisher=''[[Vatican Observatory]]''|date=23 September 2017}}</ref> His theories were also debunked by [[NASA]] and ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' writer [[Jeffrey Kluger|Jeff Kluger]], with NASA stating that Nibiru does not exist.<ref name=Time>{{cite web|last1=Kluger|first1=Jeff|title=Time Magazine Writer debunks David Meade theory, world will not end|url=http://time.com/4948315/nibiru-end-of-the-world-2017-theory/|periodical=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=19 September 2017}}</ref>
[[Albert Mohler]], the President of the [[Southern Baptist Theological Seminary]] stated, upon Meade's previous prediction in September 2017, that "Christians are not called to be the setters of dates and the anticipation of the calendar." He went on to criticize Meade's predictions saying that "this kind of thinking should be an embarrassment to Biblical Christians".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.albertmohler.com/2017/09/26/briefing-09-26-17/?segment=3|title=Tuesday, September 26, 2017 — The Briefing|website=www.albertmohler.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-23}}</ref> [[Judi McLeod]] labeled Meade as a [[false prophet#Christianity|false prophet]] on her website ''Canada Free Press'' after his prophecies failed to come true.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Merrick|first1=Dave|title=In Case You Were Planning To Float Any Long Term Loans ...|url=http://canadafreepress.com/article/in-case-you-were-planning-to-float-any-long-term-loans|quote=McLeod, Judi: This most recent false prophecy, David Meade|work=Canada Free Press|date=22 September 2017}}</ref> [[ATLAH World Missionary Church]] pastor [[James David Manning]] has also called Meade a fraud in one of his YouTube videos.<ref>{{cite web|title=David Meade Is A Fraud|last1=Manning|first1=James|url=http://politicianreviews.com/review/david-meade-is-a-fraud/|publisher=Politician Reviews|date=22 September 2017}}</ref> Brazilian astronomer [[Duília de Mello]] called his predictions and theories rubbish, and said Nibiru would have been seen during the eclipse and that Meade was using calculations based on the [[Gregorian calendar]].<ref name="Independent Mail">{{Cite web|last1=Ellis|first1=Mike|title=It's not the end of the world this weekend|url=https://www.independentmail.com/story/news/2017/09/19/its-not-end-world-weekend/680797001/|newspaper=[[The Anderson Independent-Mail]]|publisher=Gannett Company|date=19 September 2017}}</ref> British journalist [[Nick Pope (journalist)|Nick Pope]] stated that his theory had lack of critical thinking.<ref name=Nzherald/>
Meade has been compared to other failed doomsday preachers, such as [[Harold Camping]] and [[Nostradamus]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Darnay|first1=Keith|title=Doomsday prophecies fail to end anything|url=http://bismarcktribune.com/news/columnists/keith-darnay/doomsday-prophecies-fail-to-end-anything/article_83964bb4-e190-5879-9237-ee65c8b70818.html|work=[[The Bismarck Tribune]]|quote=Darnay, Keith: Nostradamus. Harold Camping. David Meade.|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> and his September 23 prediction has been compared to other failed dates, such as the [[2012 phenomenon]] and [[Year 2000 problem|Y2K]] fulfilling Christian prophecy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=May|first1=Ashley|last2=Rossman|first2=Sean|title=World ending Saturday? Here are 8 times the world was supposed to end, and didn't|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/09/21/word-ending-saturday-here-all-times-world-supposed-end-and-didnt/689011001/|newspaper=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> After September 23, 2017 passed, a European [[Telepathy|mind reader]] and [[Mentalism|mentalist]] with the same name received multiple death threats when news websites linked him to the predictions.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Phillips|first1=Kristine|title=Mind reader with same name as David Meade receives death threats after failed prediction|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2017/09/27/mind-reader-david-meade-keeps-getting-death-threats-meant-for-doomsday-theorist-david-meade/|newspaper=The Washington Post|publisher=Nash Holdings LLC|date=27 September 2017}}</ref> The man denied being the doomsday predictor and worked with a legal expert to have the false reports removed.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Sweeney|first1=Joanne|title=No, I'm not THAT David Meade says mentalist|url=https://www.irishnews.com/arts/2018/02/15/news/david-meade-i-m-not-that-david-meade--1253130/|work=[[The Irish News]]|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> Meade's ''Planet X – The 2017 Arrival'' book also received criticism as nonsense and [[plagiarism]], with only 25% being his own work.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Robert|title=Review: David Meade's "Planet X – 2017 Arrival" – A Plagiarized Scrap Book|url=http://www.science20.com/robert_walker/review_david_meades_planet_x_2017_arrival_a_plagiarized_scrap_book-227600|work=Science20.com|publisher=Robert Walker|date=22 October 2017}}</ref> On January 25, 2018, his predictions were labeled as "hype" by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' in a story about the [[Doomsday Clock]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bailey|first1=Sarah|title=Doomsday Clock: Why Americans love apocalyptic predictions|quote=Bailey, Sarah: Unlike some religious predictions in the past, including hyped predictions from people such as David Meade and Harold Camping, the scientists' clock is symbolic, and the scientists do not predict a specific date.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2018/01/25/doomsday-clock-why-americans-love-apocalyptic-predictions/|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=25 January 2018}}</ref>
== Calculations == [[File:Statue of Virgin Mary in the Cathedral of Strasbourg.jpg|right|thumb|Meade trusted that Nibiru's entry on September 23, 2017 was attached to a [[Bible code|prophetic perusing]] of the [[Woman of the Apocalypse]] (''depiction pictured'').<ref name="Bucher">{{cite web|last1=Bucher|first1=Chris|title=Meade says he got September 23rd, 2017 prediction using numerical codes in the bible|url=https://heavy.com/news/2017/09/end-of-world-september-23-nibiru-theory-hoax-real-fake-earth/|work=[[Heavy.com]]|quote=Bucher, Chris: Meade told The Washington Post his belief September 23 is the day when it all starts is based off numerical codes in several Bible verses.|date=19 September 2017}}</ref>]] [[File:All Gizah Pyramids.jpg|right|thumb|David Meade believed the 23 September prediction was [[Revelation|revealed]] to him in the Giza Pyramids, including the [[Great Pyramid at Giza|Great Pyramid]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Gadiano|first1=Jerry|title=Great Pyramid Of Giza Shows 'Exact Date The World Will End'|url=https://www.unilad.co.uk/news/great-pyramid-of-giza-shows-exact-date-the-world-will-end-and-its-soon/|work=[[UNILAD]]|year=2017}}</ref>]]
Meade told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that his September 23, 2017 prediction was based on numerical codes in the Bible.<ref name="Bucher"/> He also based his predictions on what he says are coded messages in the [[Giza pyramid complex|Giza Pyramids]] of [[Egypt]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Sudakov|first1=Dmitry|title=Date for planet Nibiru to crash into Earth encrypted in Pyramid of Giza|url=http://www.pravdareport.com/science/mysteries/18-08-2017/138453-planet_nibiru-0/|website=[[Pravda.ru]]|date=18 August 2017}}</ref> The specific focus of his prediction revolved around the [[Woman of the Apocalypse]] (referring to [[Revelation 12 sign prophecy|Revelation 12]]), another event that was supposed to take place on September 23 when a certain configuration of the Earth, Sun, Moon, and [[Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]] would happen.<ref name=graney/> He stated the significant number for his September 23 prediction is the number [[33 (number)|33]], on the grounds that "Jesus lived for 33 years" and "Elohim, the Canaanite god who was later adopted as the supreme god of ancient Israel, is mentioned 33 times in the Bible".<ref>{{cite web|last=Sheffield|first=Matthew |title=Conspiracy nuts claim an invisible rogue planet is going to bring about the Rapture|url=https://www.salon.com/2017/09/18/this-saturday-an-invisible-rogue-planet-will-bring-about-the-rapture-maybe/|work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|quote=Meade, David: understanding all of this is the number 33. In the Bible, Jesus is said to have lived for 33 years before being crucified. Elohim, the Canaanite god who was later adopted as the supreme god of ancient Israel, is mentioned 33 times in the Bible.|date=18 September 2017}}</ref> He stated several events, such as the [[solar eclipse of 21 August 2017]], [[Hurricane Harvey]], [[Hurricane Irma]], and the Mexico earthquakes were a sign that Nibiru would appear on 23 September based on the [[Bible]] chapter verse [[Luke 21|Luke 21:25–26]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Does the Bible point to a catastrophic apocalypse on September 23?|url=https://www.christiantoday.com/article/does-the-bible-point-to-a-catastrophic-apocalypse-on-september-23/113858.htm|periodical=[[Christian Today]]|date=17 September 2017|author=Staff}}</ref>
Meade's April 23 prediction was based on passage 12:1-2 in the [[Book of Revelation]], which states "And a great sign appeared in heaven: a woman clothed in the sun, with the moon under her feet and a crown of twelve stars on her head. She was pregnant and crying out in the pain and agony of giving birth".<ref name=Nzherald/> He referred to the woman as Virgo and stated that the alignment represents "the Lion of the tribe of Judah".<ref name=Nzherald/> When discussing the 7-year tribulation and [[rapture]], he stated “The Book of Revelation states that men will approach [[Armageddon]] on horseback. Nibiru is here and the earth will be prepared for the next event on its calendar. That's all in the Book of Revelation, too.”.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Narayanan|first1=Nirmal|title=Deja Vu? Doomsday prediction not on April 23, but later this year, says David Meade|url=http://amp.ibtimes.sg/deja-vu-doomsday-prediction-not-april-23-later-this-year-says-david-meade-26035|quote=Meade, David: The Book of Revelation states that men will approach Armageddon on horseback. Nibiru is here and the earth will be prepared for the next event on its calendar. That's all in the Book of Revelation, too.|publisher=[[International Business Times]]|date=21 April 2018}}</ref>

(2 May 2013) ''Fraud Prevention''. Self-published on eBookIt.com ASIN B00CMJO7U6 * Meade, David. (22 May 2013) ''Mysterious Islands''. Self-published on eBookit.com. ASIN B00CY2OA3K * Meade, David. (17 July 2013 ) ''Research for Writers''. Self-published on eBookit.com. ASIN B00E0MKDFQ * Meade, David. (21 June 2014) ''You Can Write a Best-Selling Info Book!'' Self-published on eBookit.com. ASIN B00L72JDUI * Meade, David. (12 September 2014) ''Web Design for Authors: Every Author Needs a Website!''. Self-published on eBookit.com. ASIN B00NJBT184 * Meade, David. Self-published on eBookIt.com {{ISBN|9781456626235}} * {{cite book|last1=Meade|first1=David|title=Planet X – The 2017 Arrival|date=9 February 2016|publisher=Self published on eBookIt.com |isbn=9781456626921|edition=Paperback|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=AHMqDwAAQBAJ|language=English}} * Meade, David. '''Donnar A. Dromberg''' (22 September 1908 – 27 June 1992)<ref>''[http://www.abps.org.uk/Awards/Roll_of_Distinguished_Philatelists/RDP_Background_20111231_LR.pdf Background notes on The Roll of Distinguished Philatelists September 2011]'', Roll of Distinguished Philatelists Trust, London, 2011. [https://www.webcitation.org/6OlHSBOTl Archived here.]</ref> was a Finnish [[philatelist]] who was added to the [[Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] in 1977. He was an expert in the philately of South America.
Dromberg was the special representative for Finland for the [[Royal Philatelic Society London]].
==Selected publications== *''Via Gothenberg''. Finnish Philatelic Federation.

revision.comment: Doesn't necessarily make him an activist. It was signed by all of the Provisional State Council
revision.text:
[[File:Eliyahu Dobkin David Ben Gurion1947.jpg|thumb|right|Eliyahu Dobkin (seated right) and his wife speaking with [[David Ben-Gurion]] (2nd from left) at [[Lod Airport]] before their flight to New York, May 1947.]] '''Eliyahu Dobkin''' ({{lang-he|אליהו דובקין}}, 31 December 1898 – 26 October 1976) was a leading figure of the [[Labor Zionism]] movement, a signatory of the [[Israeli Declaration of Independence]] and a founder of the [[Israel Museum]]. He was also active in the [[Jewish Agency for Israel|Jewish Agency]] and the [[World Zionist Organisation]].
==Biography== Eliyahu Dobkin was born in [[Babruysk]] in the [[Russian Empire]] (today in [[Belarus]]) to a [[Religious Zionism|religious-Zionist]] family. His father, Yosef, worked in the lumber and banking industries, and was a member of the [[Mizrachi (Religious Zionism)|Mizrahi]] movement. Dobkin was schooled in a [[heder]] and [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] and later studied in [[Kharkiv]] (today in [[Ukraine]]), where he founded the Zionist student movement ''HaHaver'' in 1914. In 1917 he joined the [[HeHalutz]] movement founded in the same year by [[Joseph Trumpeldor]].
After [[World War I]] the family fled the [[Bolsheviks]] and settled in [[Białystok]] in [[Poland]]. In 1921 he was elected general secretary of the world HeHalutz movement, which was headquartered in [[Warsaw]]. There he met [[Simcha Blass]], who would later marry Dobkin's sister Yehudit.
On 6 June 1932 Dobkin [[aliyah|immigrated]] to [[Mandatory Palestine|Mandate Palestine]] with his wife and daughter and settled in [[Tel Aviv]]. That year he became a member of the [[Histadrut]] trade union. Between 1933 and 1968 he was a member of the Zionist Workers' Committee. In 1936 he joined the Jewish Agency, and headed its immigration department during [[World War II]] with the responsibility for rescuing [[Jews]] from Europe and [[Aliyah Bet|illegal Jewish immigration]] to Mandate Palestine.<ref>[http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/AboutIsrael/IsraelAt50/Pages/The%20Signatories%20of%20the%20Declaration%20of%20the%20Establis.aspx The Signatories of the Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel] Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs</ref> He became a member of its executive in 1946.
When Israel declared independence on 14 May 1948, Dobkin was one of the designated signatories. However, at the time he was trapped in [[Siege of Jerusalem (1948)|besieged]] [[Jerusalem]], and added his signature at a later point. In the same year he became head of [[Keren Hayesod]], a post he held until 1961. In 1951 he also took over as head of the Jewish Agency's youth and HeHalutz, serving until 1968.
An art collector, Dobkin was head of the [[Bezalel Academy of Art and Design|Bezalel museum]] and later founded the [[Israel Museum]], sitting on its board until his death.

([[Sibling#Three-quarter|three-quarter sister]]) | color = #F0E68C }} '''Eric van der Woodsen''' (spelled '''Erik''' in the novels) is a fictional character from the book series ''[[Gossip Girl (novel series)|Gossip Girl]]'' and the [[Gossip Girl (TV series)|television series of the same name]], in which he is portrayed by [[Connor Paolo]]. ==Novel series== Erik is described as similar to every van der Woodsen: tall, thin, and blonde. The younger brother of [[Serena van der Woodsen]], Erik van der Woodsen is not featured in the books very often. A junior at [[Brown University]], Serena has said he has "at least six or seven different girlfriends he sleeps with routinely." On a trip to [[Sun Valley, Idaho|Sun Valley]], Erik and Serena’s best friend [[Blair Waldorf]] dated briefly. Very close to his sister, Erik threw her a giant [[sweet sixteen (birthday)|sweet sixteenth birthday bash]] and drove her up to Hanover on her first day of school there. Aside from his brief appearances, Erik remained a relatively quiet secondary character throughout the series, however he did have a bigger part in the ''Gossip Girl'' prequel, ''[[Gossip Girl (novel series)#Gossip Girl|Gossip Girl: It Had to Be You]]''. ==TV series== ===Characterization=== In contrast to the novels, Eric's character is more complex in the show, showing a mature understanding of family and relationships but faces the same troubles as most teenagers have. [[Alessandra Stanley]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' mentions his character's deviation from the novels from "an object of female lust" to one of "...psychotherapy." But notes his strong bond with Serena, stating how he "is misunderstood by all but his caring, if troubled, sister." {{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/19/arts/television/19goss.html | archiveurl = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/19/arts/television/19goss.html | archivedate = 19 September 2007 | title = Reading, Writing and Raunch: Mean Girls Rule Prep School | work = [[The New York Times]] | first = Alessandra | last = Stanley| authorlink = Alessandra Stanley | date = 11 March 2011}} Despite his mature persona, Eric is no stranger to the problems that most teens face as his stay at the Ostroff Center, a rehabilitation facility, is a result of his constant loneliness and his mother's many unstable marriages. Connor Paolo notes that Eric's lack of a father figure contributed to his suicide attempt.{{cite web | url = http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/02/connor_paolo_wants_eric_van_de.html | archiveurl = http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/02/connor_paolo_wants_eric_van_de.html | archivedate = 16 February 2010 | title = Connor Paolo Wants Eric Van Der Woodsen to Go Postal | work = The New York Times | first = Alexandra | last = Martell | date = 16 February 2010}} ===Season 1=== At the beginning of the season, Eric has been living at the Ostroff Center, a high-class mental facility. Serena frequently visits him after coming back. As well as trying to convince the doctors and her mother Lilly to let him out. They let Eric out temporarily, during the Ivy League Mixer, where he develops a friendship with [[Jenny Humphrey]]. After [[Blair Waldorf]] humiliates his sister, telling the whole school she was attending the Ostroff Center during her absence having mistakenly seeing photos of Serena entering the center, Eric tells Blair he was the one attending the mental center and shows her the scars on his wrists from his [[suicide]] attempt. At Blair's annual sleepover, Blair dares Jenny to break into the Ostroff Center and take Eric out for the night. Jenny and Blair succeed and they take him to a bar downtown. Lily is made aware of his disappearance and begins to panic. She quickly informs [[Rufus Humphrey|Rufus]], whose son, [[Dan Humphrey|Dan]], is on a date with Serena, after she cannot get hold of her. They contact the couple to make sure Eric is alright and to bring him home. Later, Lily realizes that Eric is ready to come out of the medical center. He is present during Thanksgiving dinner at the Humphrey's apartment when Lily and Rufus reveal they had a previous relationship years ago. Due to his mother's engagement to billionaire [[Bart Bass]], he develops a close friendship with [[Chuck Bass]], whom he soon sees as a brother. He tries to warn Jenny about her new boyfriend Asher Hornsby ([[Jesse Swenson]]) but she mistakes this for Eric being in love with her. In the same episode, Dan and [[Georgina Sparks]] see Asher making out with someone outside of school. The news becomes public on Gossip Girl, and Jenny denies the rumor by saying she lost her [[virginity]] to Asher, which Eric knows is untrue. During a dinner with his family, Georgina [[Coming out|outs]] him to get back at Serena. Eric's [[homosexuality]] upsets Lily, who blames herself for Eric getting institutionalized. Serena comforts him, and learns that Eric already came out to Chuck before her because he knew Chuck wouldn't judge him. He also explains that he had a relationship with someone while at the Ostroff Center, but now believed that it was over. At Asher and Jenny's party, Eric helps Blair dethrone Jenny by revealing that Asher was indeed [[gay]], and that they were involved. Asher denies this, but Blair sends a Gossip Girl blast with Eric and Asher's emails. He and Lilly later reconcile. ===Season 2=== During summer 2008, Eric is staying with his sister and grandmother in The Hamptons. He receives a call from Jenny who tells him, she needs help to get in the Vitamin White Party. She apologizes to him about the incident with Asher and they become friends again. Eric introduces [[Tinsley Mortimer]] to Jenny to extend her contacts in the fashion industry. After the school year starts, although Serena complains about Lily's new marriage and their new house rules, Eric thinks they should give the marriage a chance. Later, Eric introduces Jonathan Whitney ([[Matt Doyle (actor)|Matt Doyle]]) as his new boyfriend. They break up after Bart tells Eric that Jonathan has been cheating on him. Eric lodges Jenny secretly in the Bass-van der Woodsen penthouse and goes with her to make the paperwork to divorce her parents. Eric then discovers that Bart hired his private detective, Andrew Tyler, to do research about his, Lily's, and Serena's past. He discovers that Lily was also institutionalized at a French sanatorium and that she didn't tell him so that she could be strong for him. Bart's actions convince Lily to celebrate Thanksgiving with the Humphreys. After Bart's death, Eric comes back with Jonathan and tries to convince Chuck to go back to their penthouse. Chuck and Eric officially go from close friends to brothers after Lily adopts her late husband's son. ===Season 3=== During summer 2009, Eric is in his grandmother's house with Jenny, Dan, and Rufus while Lily is in Montecito taking care of his and Serena's grandmother, CeCe. He observes Jenny's speech to the rest of Constance that end the school hierarchy. During Jenny's gradual transformation as an Upper East Side Queen, he falls victim to Jenny and her cronies when a battle over the steps that Jonathan inadvertently started and ends with Eric being splattered with yogurt. The Halloween party that followed after had Jonathan being egged at the club opening, enraging Eric, who tells Jenny he wants nothing to do with her. Eric sabotages Jenny's Cotillion by falsely sending a text to Graham Collins, the date Jenny wants using her phone which claims that Jonathan will be taking her to Cotillion. He joins forces with Blair, whom Jenny also offends publicly, in making Kira Abernathy, a Constance student whom Jenny regularly ignores, a threat to Jenny's reign as Queen. Blair gives Kira a makeover and Eric blackmails Graham into becoming Kira's escort instead of Jenny. Jenny soon endures public humiliation but manages to gain their respect by taking Nate as her escort for Cotillion. These events cause Jonathan to break up with Eric as he claims Eric has changed now that he's resorted to scheming with Blair. After Cotillion, Jenny leaves with the other Upper East Side Queen Bees and leaves unaware that Eric has been responsible for her public embarrassment. At Thanksgiving, Jenny discovers that Eric was the one behind her public embarrassment at Cotillion which sets her getting her revenge on him. Eric teams up with Kira and attempts to ruin Jenny by buying one of his accomplices the same bag as her and have the girls turn against her. This fails as Jenny reveals two identical bags handing them over to his accomplices, falsely apologizing for her actions but claiming that one of the girls whom Erica bought a bag for spoiled her surprise. Eric and Jenny then to a truce after Serena's car accident. It is revealed in "Inglourious Bassterds" that Eric was in Japan and ends up meeting a potential love-interest named Elliot (Luke Kleintank) during a game of [[Assassin (game)|assassin]] on Nate's birthday.{{cite web | url = http://www.afterelton.com/blog/dennis/gossip-girl-317-eric-gets-a-love-interest | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100512170145/http://www.afterelton.com/blog/dennis/gossip-girl-317-eric-gets-a-love-interest | archivedate = 12 May 2010 | title = Eric's New and Surprisingly Hot "Gossip Girl" Love Interest | publisher = [[afterElton.com]] | first = Dennis | last = Ayers | date = 6 April 2010 | deadurl = yes | df = }} On the day of Blair's maid's, Dorota, wedding, Eric wonders if Elliot is gay and discovers that he has a girlfriend during the wedding reception. Elliot then confides in Eric that he is [[bisexual]], indicating that Eric still has a chance with him when Elliot tells him that his girlfriend left out of jealousy.{{cite web | url = http://www.afterelton.com/blog/dennis/gossip-girl-318-bisexual-mating-dance | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100519114342/http://www.afterelton.com/blog/dennis/gossip-girl-318-bisexual-mating-dance | archivedate = 19 May 2010 | title = Last Night's ''Gossip Girl'': The Bisexual Mating Dance | publisher = afterElton.com | first = Dennis | last = Ayers | date = 13 April 2010 | deadurl = yes | df = }} Eric's relationship with his father, William, is also observed when he coldly rejects him for not being there for him. He informs him that he is gay and had been institutionalized. His friendship with Jenny is once again tested when she reveals that she aided his father's escape from the police. He coldly states that no one is forcing Jenny to stay and that she can leave if she wants to. Eric is the first to discover that Jenny lost her virginity to Chuck and tries to comfort a dismayed Jenny, who is sent away to finish high school in [[Hudson, New York|Hudson]]. ===Season 4=== In "[[The Undergraduates]]", Chuck tries to make amends with Rufus and Eric, by coming to Fashion Week with his new girlfriend, Eva. Eric, however, informs Rufus of Chuck's season 1 assault on Jenny and says that his brother has been given too many chances to redeem himself, signaling the end of their once-close bond. When Jenny returns to the Upper East Side briefly for an interview with Tim Gunn, Eric attempts to help her make a good impression and keep her away from both Chuck and Blair. Later, he and Dan scheme against Blair and Chuck to get Jenny to come back for their parents' anniversary. The plan fails when Blair and Chuck sign a treaty and come to a truce. After Dan steals the treaty from Nate, Eric backs out of the plan. Eric unknowingly leads his parents to Blair's party where Dan's plan is about to go through, thinking Dan had abandoned the plan. Eric is present when Serena is admitted to the Ostroff Center. He is proud of her for going, but does not believe her when she denies overdosing. He is also present when Serena confronts Lily. Pepe angry at his mother for what happened to Ben Donovan and Bass Industries. When man from the Empire calls saying the judge from Ben's case was there, Eric calls Serena, which makes her determined to take Lily down. In "Damien Darko", it is revealed that Eric and Elliot broke up and he has been lying to his mother about being with Elliot when he has really been with Damien. When Jonathan goes with Eric to the W party, Eric ditches Jonathan to meet up with Damien. However, earlier Ben had seen Eric with Damien and called Serena. When they walk in on Eric and Damien, the two pretend to be couple and Ben lectures Eric about making bad choices. Eric promises not to see Damien anymore. Rufus confronts Eric, asking if he bought drugs from Damien and Eric says he bought some pills, but realizes it was stupid and promises to stop. But while he keeps that promise, when Damien calls Eric after Ben warns him away from Serena's family, Eric agrees to hang out with him. ===Season 5=== Rufus reveals in the season 5 premiere "[[Yes, Then Zero]]" that Jenny and Eric have moved to London to attend Saint Martins. During the episode "Memoirs of an Invisible Dan", it's mentioned that in Dan's semi-autobiographical novel ''Inside'' Nate and Eric's literary counterparts were meshed together. ===Season 6=== Eric returns briefly for the series finale. ==Reception== ''[[TVLine|TV Line]]'s'' [[Michael Ausiello]] had reported that Connor Paolo had originally been offered to become a series regular for the show's second season but kindly declined. “I’m very happy with my position on the show and I have no interest in changing it,” and that he may not be ready to face the same challenges as his other castmates stating that “Watching Blake [Lively] and Penn [Badgley] and the things they have to deal with as [a full-time cast members]… because they are on the posters and they are the face of the show, is not something I’m totally ready for right now.” ==References== {{reflist}} {{Gossip Girl}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woodsen, Eric Van Der}} [[Category:Fictional American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2002]] [[Category:Fictional attempted suicides]] [[Category:Fictional college students]] [[Category:Fictional gay males]] [[Category:Fictional LGBT characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional models]] [[Category:Fictional socialites]] [[Category:Gossip Girl characters]] [[Category:Male characters in literature]] [[Category:Male characters in television]] [[Category:Teenage characters in television]]

CollegeHOF = 50053 }} '''Francis Asbury Tarkenton''' (born February 3, 1940) is a former [[National Football League]] (NFL) quarterback, television personality, and computer software executive. He played in the NFL for 18 seasons and spent the majority of his career with the [[Minnesota Vikings]].
Tarkenton's tenure with the Vikings spanned thirteen non-consecutive seasons, playing with the team for six seasons from 1961 to 1966, then for seven seasons from 1972 to 1978. In between his years in Minnesota, Tarkenton was a member of the [[New York Giants]] for five seasons. At the time of his retirement, Tarkenton owned every major quarterback record. He was inducted into the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] in 1986 and the [[College Football Hall of Fame]] in 1987.
In addition to his football career, Tarkenton served as a commentator on ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' and a co-host of ''[[That's Incredible!]]''. He also founded Tarkenton Software, a computer-program generator company, and he toured the U.S. promoting CASE ([[computer-aided software engineering]]) with [[Albert F. Case Jr.]] of Nastec Corporation. Tarkenton Software later merged with [[KnowledgeWare]] (with Tarkenton as president), until selling the company to [[Sterling Software]] in 1994.
==Early life and education== {{moresources|section|date=December 2017}} Fran Tarkenton was born on February 3, 1940, in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. His father, Dallas Tarkenton, was a [[Methodist]] minister.<ref name=losing/> Tarkenton went to [[Clarke Central High School|Athens High School]] in [[Athens, Georgia]], and later attended the [[University of Georgia]], where he was the quarterback on the [[Georgia Bulldogs football|Bulldog football team]] and a member of the [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] fraternity.
Under Coach [[Wally Butts]] and with Tarkenton as quarterback, Georgia won the 1959 [[List of Southeastern Conference champions#Football|Southeastern Conference championship]]. Tarkenton was a first-team All-SEC selection in both 1959 and 1960.
==Professional football career== The [[Minnesota Vikings]] [[NFL draft|drafted]] Tarkenton in the third round of the [[1961 NFL Draft]], and he was picked in the fifth round of the [[1961 American Football League Draft|1961 AFL draft]] by the [[Boston Patriots]]. He signed with the Vikings. Tarkenton, 21, played his first [[National Football League]] game (and the Vikings' first game) on September 17 against the [[Chicago Bears]] coming off the bench to lead the Vikings to a come-from-behind victory by passing for 250 yards and four touchdown passes and running for another<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/photos/0ap1000000145639/0ap2000000154091|title=Countdown to the 2013 NFL Draft|work=[[National Football League]]|accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref> as the Vikings defeated the Bears 37–13. He was the only player in NFL history to pass for four touchdowns in his first NFL game, until the feat was repeated by [[Marcus Mariota]] in the [[Tennessee Titans]]' 2015 season opener versus the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]].<ref>"[http://www.titansonline.com/news/article-4/A-Look-at-Marcus-Mariotas-Rookie-Accomplishments/107490e1-afe4-4337-a855-170574e45aaa A Look at Marcus Mariota's Rookie Accomplishments]" by Jim Wyatt, [[Tennessee Titans|Titans]] online, December 31, 2015</ref> [[File:Tarkenton Scrambling.PNG|thumb|160px|left|Tarkenton [[Quarterback scramble|scrambling]] (1974)]] He played for the Vikings from [[1961 NFL season|1961]] to [[1966 NFL season|1966]]. His early years with the team were plagued by the trouble expected for a newly created team, with the Vikings winning a total of 10 games combined in their first three seasons, with Tarkenton winning eight of them. He threw 18 touchdowns and 17 interceptions for 1,997 yards in his first season. He rushed for 308 yards on 56 rushes for five touchdowns. The following year, he threw 22 touchdowns and 25 interceptions for 2,595 yards. He rushed for 361 yards on 41 rushes for two touchdowns.
Tarkenton was traded to the [[New York Giants]] in [[1967 NFL season|1967]], at which time he moved to the New York City suburb of [[New Rochelle, New York]].<ref>Kriegel, Mark. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2LttIGhZtWIC&pg=PA210 Namath:A Biography]''; Penguin Books; 2005; {{ISBN|978-0143035350}}; p.210</ref> In the first game of the [[1969 NFL season|1969]] season, Tarkenton's Giants played the Vikings. After trailing 23–10 in the fourth quarter, Tarkenton threw two touchdown passes to secure a 24–23 comeback victory over his former team.<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/196909210nyg.htm "Minnesota Vikings at New York Giants - September 21st, 1969"], Pro-Football-Reference.com</ref> The 24 points allowed by Minnesota's defense were a season-worst for the unit, one more point than the Vikings allowed in losing [[Super Bowl IV]] to the [[1969 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]].<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/min/1969.htm "1969 Minnesota Vikings"], Pro-Football-Reference.com</ref>
Tarkenton enjoyed his best season with the Giants in [[1970 NFL season|1970]]. The club overcame an 0-3 start to win nine of 10 and move into position to win the [[NFC East]] division championship in week 14. However, New York was routed 31-3 by the [[1970 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] at Yankee Stadium, leaving the Giants 9-5, one game behind the division champion [[1970 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] and the wild card [[1970 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]]. 1970 was the closest the Giants came to making the playoffs during a 17-year drought, spanning the [[1964 NFL season|1964]] through [[1980 NFL season|1980]] seasons.
Tarkenton was traded back to Minnesota in [[1972 NFL season|1972]], for three players ([[Norm Snead]], [[Bob Grim (American football)|Bob Grim]] and [[Vince Clements]]), plus a first and second round draft choice.<ref>"[https://www.si.com/vault/1972/02/07/565932/scramble-back-to-the-deep-purple Scramble Back To The Deep Purple]", ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', February 7, 1971</ref> He led the Vikings to three [[National Football Conference]] championships, but in each instance the Vikings lost the ensuing [[Super Bowl]]. In Tarkenton's first Super Bowl appearance his team lost to the [[Miami Dolphins]] 24–7 in [[Houston]]. It lost the second to the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] 16–6 in [[New Orleans]], and in the last Super Bowl Tarkenton played (and Minnesota's last Super Bowl to date), the Vikings lost to the [[Oakland Raiders]] 32–14 at the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] in [[Pasadena, California]].
In his 18 NFL seasons, Tarkenton completed 3,686 of 6,467 passes for 47,003 yards and 342 touchdowns, with 266 interceptions, all of which were NFL records at the time of his retirement. Tarkenton's 47,003 career passing yards rank him 8th all time, while his 342 career passing touchdowns is 6th all time in NFL history.<ref>{{citation |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/nfl/10/11/manning.tds.ap/index.html |title=Manning Passes Tarkenton with 343rd Career TD |work=Sports Illustrated |date=2009-10-11 |accessdate=2009-10-12}}</ref> He also is 6th on the [[most wins by a starting quarterback (NFL)|all-time list of wins by a starting quarterback]] with 124 regular season victories. He also used his impressive [[Quarterback scramble|scrambling]] ability to rack up 3,674 rushing yards and 32 touchdowns on 675 carries. During his career, Tarkenton ran for a touchdown in 15 different seasons, an NFL record among quarterbacks. He ranks fifth in career rushing yards among quarterbacks, behind [[Randall Cunningham]], [[Steve Young (American football)|Steve Young]], [[Michael Vick]] and [[Cam Newton]]. He is also one of two NFL quarterbacks ever to rush for at least 300 yards in seven different seasons; the other is [[Tobin Rote]]. When he retired, Tarkenton held NFL career records in pass attempts, completions, yardage, and touchdowns; rushing yards by a quarterback; and wins by a starting quarterback. [[File:Fran Tarkenton.png|thumb|140px|Tarkenton launching a [[forward pass]] (1965)]] The Vikings finished the 1975 season with an NFC-best 12–2 record and Tarkenton won the [[NFL Most Valuable Player Award]] and the [[NFL Offensive Player of the Year Award]] while capturing [[All-Pro]] honors in the process. He was also a second-team All-Pro in 1973 and earned All-NFC selections in 1972 and 1976. He was named second-team All-NFC in 1970 and 1974. Tarkenton was selected to play in nine [[Pro Bowl]]s.<ref name=pro>[http://www.profootballhof.com/players/fran-tarkenton/biography/ Tarkenton], Professional Football Hall of Fame website</ref>
Tarkenton was indecisive on his retirement during the last seven years of his playing career.<ref>"[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/597433112.html?dids=597433112:597433112&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Aug+10%2C+1971&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Tarkenton+Has+Retired%2C+Giants+Say&pqatl=google Tarkenton Has Retired, Giants Say]", ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', Αugust 10, 1971</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AuASAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AfsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1995,6086312&dq=fran+tarkenton+retire Quote Of The Day], ''[[The Ledger]]'', March 22, 1978</ref>
Despite not winning a Super Bowl, he won six playoff games, and in 1999 he was ranked #59 on ''[[The Sporting News]]'' list of the 100 Greatest Football Players.
Tarkenton was inducted into the [[Georgia Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1977,<ref>[http://gshf.org/inductees/list.php?id=382 Inductees], Georgia Hall of Fame website</ref> the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] in 1986,<ref name=pro/> the [[College Football Hall of Fame]] in 1987,<ref>[http://www.cfbhall.com/inductees/ Inductees], [[College Football Hall of Fame]] website</ref> and the [[Athens, Georgia]] Athletic Hall of Fame in 2000.<ref>[http://www.athenshalloffame.com/inductees.html 2000 Inductees] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822025541/http://www.athenshalloffame.com/inductees.html |date=2016-08-22 }}, Athens Hall of Fame website</ref>
==Books== A biography of Tarkenton titled ''Better Scramble than Lose'' was published in 1969.<ref>[[Jack Olsen|Olsen, Jack]]. ''Better Scramble Than Lose''; Four Winds Press; 1969</ref> This followed Tarkenton's 1967 autobiography ''No Time for Losing'' and preceded by several years his 1977 autobiography ''Tarkenton'' co-written with [[Jim Klobuchar]]. The autobiographies chronicle not only his football career but also his personal evolution from his early football days as a preacher's son. Tarkenton co-wrote with [[Brock Yates]] a book in 1971 titled ''Broken Patterns: The Education of a Quarterback'', a chronicle of the 1970 [[New York Giants]] season.<ref>Tarkenton, Fran & Brock W. Yates. ''Broken Patterns: The Education of a Quarterback''; Simon and Schuster, 1971, {{ISBN|978-0671210533}}</ref>
In 1986, Tarkenton, with author Herb Resincow, wrote a novel titled ''Murder at the Super Bowl'', the [[whodunit]] story of a football coach killed just before his team is to participate in the championship game.<ref>Tarkenton, Fran & Herb Resincow. ''Murder at the Super Bowl''; William Morrow & Co; 1st edition : October 1986; {{ISBN|978-0688067168}}</ref>
Tarkenton wrote the self-help, motivational books ''Playing to Win'' in 1984,<ref>Tarkenton, Fran, Playing to Win, 1985, Bantam Books {{ISBN|0-553-25079-5}}</ref> and ''How to Motivate People: The Team Strategy for Success'' in 1986.<ref>Tarkenton, Fran and Tuleja, Tad 1986, Harper and Row {{ISBN|0-06-015543-4}}</ref> He also wrote the motivational self-help business book titled ''What Losing Taught Me About Winning'',<ref name=losing>Tarkenton Fran. ''What Losing Taught Me About Winning: The Ultimate Guide for Success in Small and Home-Based Businesses ''; Fireside Books; 1997; {{ISBN|0-684-83879-6}}</ref> and ''Every Day is Game Day''.<ref>Tarkenton, Fran and Bruton, Jim. ''Every Day Is Game Day''; Triumph Books; 2009; {{ISBN|1-60078-253-1}}</ref> In 1987, Tarkenton hosted a ''[[Think and Grow Rich]]'' TV infomercial that sold the book with an audio cassette version (the audio cassettes contained an introduction and conclusion by Tarkenton).<ref>"[http://www.guthy-renker.com.au/awms/Upload/Resources/Response_Magazine.pdf Partners in Time : Guthy-Renker, Charles Wesley Orton]", ''Response'' magazine, May 2001</ref>
==Business ventures and investments== [[Mark McCormack]] helped Tarkenton invest, making him wealthy enough to "retire this week if [he] wanted to", as [[New York (magazine)|''New York'']] magazine wrote in 1971.<ref name=ax>Axthelm, Pete. "[https://books.google.com/books?id=A-MCAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA34&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q&f=true "The Third Annual Permanent Retirement of Joe Namath]", ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, July 7, 1971, pp.47-49</ref> Tarkenton was a pioneer in computer software, and founder of Tarkenton Software, a program generator company. He toured the United States promoting CASE or "[[computer-aided software engineering]]" with [[Albert F. Case, Jr.]] of Nastec Corporation, but ultimately merged his software firm with [[James Martin (author)|James Martin]]'s [[KnowledgeWare]], of which Tarkenton was president until selling the company to [[Sterling Software]] in 1994.
In 1999, Tarkenton was fined by federal regulators as part of a securities fraud sweep. According to the ''[[LA Times]]'', "In Tarkenton's case, the Hall of Fame quarterback and 10 other former executives of his computer software and consulting firm, KnowledgeWare Inc., were accused of inflating by millions of dollars the company's earnings in reports for its fiscal year ended June 30, 1994. The former Minnesota Vikings quarterback agreed to pay a $100,000 fine and $54,187 in restitution. He did not admit any wrongdoing".<ref>''[[LA Times]]'', September 29, 1999</ref>
Since then, Tarkenton has been promoting various products and services including [[Tony Robbins]] and [[BarNone|1-800-BAR-NONE]]. He also founded GoSmallBiz, a small-business consulting website. He also operates an [[annuity]] marketing firm called Tarkenton Financial.
==Politics== [[File:Fran Tarkenton 2016 RNC.jpg|thumb|Tarkenton speaking at the 2016 Republican National Convention]] During the [[2016 Republican National Convention]], Tarkenton gave a speech endorsing Republican presidential nominee [[Donald Trump]].<ref>"[http://www.startribune.com/vikings-veteran-fran-tarkenton-speaks-at-republican-convention/387879322/ Vikings veteran Fran Tarkenton speaks at Republican convention]", ''[[Star Tribune]]'', July 21, 2016</ref>
