{{about|the English actor|other people|James Norton (disambiguation)}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = James Norton | image =James Norton at Cambridge.jpg | caption = Norton, on [[Clare College Bridge]], [[Cambridge]]
during filming for ''[[Grantchester (TV series)|Grantchester]]'', 2015 | alt = James Norton filming TV series Grantchester on Clare College Bridge in Cambridge in 205 | birth_name=James Geoffrey Ian Norton | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1985|7|18}} | birth_place = [[London]], England, UK | education = [[Ampleforth College]], [[Yorkshire]]
(independent Roman Catholic boarding school) | alma_mater = [[University of Cambridge]], [[Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge]]
[[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] | residence = [[Peckham]], London | height = {{height|ft=6|in=1}} | occupation = Actor | years_active = 2007–present | home_town = [[Malton, North Yorkshire]] }} '''James Geoffrey Ian Norton'''{{cite web|accessdate=29 September 2017|url=https://www.mrporter.com/journal/the-look/the-rise-of-mr-james-norton/2612|title=The Rise of Mr. James Norton|publisher=Mr. Porter|first=Richard|last=Godwin|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929194835/https://www.mrporter.com/journal/the-look/the-rise-of-mr-james-norton/2612|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} (born 18 July 1985) is an English actor. He is best known for roles in the British TV series ''[[Happy Valley (TV series)|Happy Valley]]'', ''[[Grantchester (TV series)|Grantchester]]'', ''[[War & Peace (2016 TV series)|War & Peace]] and [[McMafia]].'' For his role as ex-convict Tommy Lee Royce in ''Happy Valley'', Norton was nominated for the [[British Academy Television Award for Best Supporting Actor]] in 2015.{{cite news |last1=Shattuck|first1=Kathryn|title=Easily Channeling a Vulnerable Vicar: James Norton in ‘Grantchester’ on PBS ‘Masterpiece’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/11/arts/television/james-norton-in-grantchester-on-pbs-masterpiece.html|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 January 2015}} Norton was educated at the [[University of Cambridge]], where he read theology and performed in student theatre productions. ==Early life== Norton was born in [[London]], the son of Lavinia Jane (Norman) and Hugh Biddulph Norton.{{cite web|url=http://www.famechain.com/family-tree/21067/hugh-norton/lavinia-norton|title=Hugh Norton & Lavinia Norton Engagement, Children, Joint Family Tree & History - FameChain|website=Famechain.com|accessdate=13 October 2017}} His parents were both teachers; his father, who was born in [[Tanzania]], was a Lecturer at [[Hull College|Hull School of Art and Design]].{{cite news|last1=Norton|first1=Graham Norton|title=James Norton, Graham Norton — BBC Radio 2|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03dgqg8|accessdate=3 January 2016|work=[[BBC Radio 2]]|date=2 January 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/tv-radio/479237/Happy-Valley-s-James-Norton-on-Grantchester |title='I admire Michael Fassbender enormously,' says Happy Valley's James Norton |last1=Williams |first1=Andrew |date=1 June 2014 |work= [[The Sunday Express]] |accessdate=20 June 2014}} Though originally from London, Norton's family lived in the town of [[Malton, North Yorkshire|Malton]] in the [[Ryedale]] district of [[North Yorkshire]].{{cite news|title=How James Norton went from killer to clergyman|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/yorkshire-living/arts/theatre-and-tv/how-james-norton-went-from-killer-to-clergyman-1-6869080|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Yorkshire Post]]|date=5 October 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/theatre/9036732.Review__Journey___s_End__Leeds_Grand_Theatre/ |title=Review: Journey's End, Leeds Grand Theatre |last1=Hutchinson |first1=Charles |date=19 May 2011 |work= [[The Press (York)]] |accessdate=27 December 2013}} Norton, who grew up at the edge of the [[Howardian Hills]] in North Yorkshire, has described his childhood as "idyllic." Norton's ancestry is English, Irish, Scottish, [[Cornish people|Cornish]] and [[Jewish]].{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3584268/bio|title=James Norton|website=IMDb|accessdate=18 August 2018}} ===Education=== Norton was educated at [[Ampleforth College]],{{cite journal|title=All the world’s a stage (page 13) |journal=Optima |date=Autumn 2007 |issue=13 |page=13 |url=http://www.fitz.cam.ac.uk/mi-client/media/import/documents/Optima13.pdf |accessdate=10 January 2015 |publisher=[[Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228144657/http://www.fitz.cam.ac.uk/mi-client/media/import/documents/Optima13.pdf |archivedate=28 December 2013 }} an independent [[Roman Catholic]] ([[Benedictine]]) boarding school in the village of [[Ampleforth]] in North Yorkshire. He did work experience at the [[Stephen Joseph Theatre]] in [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]] when he was 15. Starting in 2004, Norton read [[theology]] at [[Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge]], graduating in 2007 with First Class Honours. Norton received a Fitzwilliam Travel Grant to travel to Northern India, to teach and perform for schoolchildren at 16 schools. He has said his studies were principally focused on Hinduism and Buddhism. Norton was a member of [[the Marlowe Society]] theatre club at Cambridge, and in 2007, he played Posthumus in a production of ''[[Cymbeline]]'' directed by [[Trevor Nunn]] for the society's centenary.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/3668124/The-Marlowe-Society-Talent-show-for-theatres-brightest-stars.html |title=The Marlowe Society: Talent show for theatre's brightest stars |last1=Christiansen |first1=Rupert |date=24 September 2007|work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=29 December 2013}} Norton has said that he performed in many theatre productions while in college.{{cite web|title=James Norton|url=http://www.theartistspartnership.co.uk/norton/269/#.VLFhxivF98E|website=The Artists Partnership|accessdate=10 January 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Merry|first1=Elspeth|title=James Norton|url=http://www.1883magazine.com/film/film/james-norton|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=1883 Magazine|date=28 April 2014}} Norton then attended the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] (RADA) in London for three years, but left in 2010 six months before graduation to take an acting assignment.{{cite news|last1=Watson |first1=Jonathan|title=James Norton: Joining the big league|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/people/2011/11/james-norton-joining-the-big-league/|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Stage (magazine)|The Stage]]|date=4 November 2011}} ==Career== Norton appeared as Jenny's boyfriend in the film ''[[An Education]]'', starring [[Carey Mulligan]], in 2009. In 2010, he was an original cast member of ''[[Posh (play)|Posh]]'' at the [[Royal Court Theatre]].{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/apr/16/posh-royal-court-billington |title='Posh' – Royal Court, London |last1=Billington |first1=Michael |date=16 April 2010 |work= [[The Guardian]] |accessdate=29 December 2013}} At the [[Crucible Theatre]] in [[Sheffield]] in 2010, Norton starred in ''[[That Face]]'' as Henry, an 18-year-old who has dropped out of school to care for his mentally disturbed and drug-dependent mother, played by [[Frances Barber]]. Lynne Walker of ''The Independent'' wrote of his performance: "At the centre of it all is Henry who, in James Norton's striking portrayal, is like a young caged animal".{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/reviews/that-face-crucible-studio-sheffield-2022104.html |title='That Face, Crucible Studio, Sheffield |last1=Walker |first1=Lynne |date=9 July 2010 |work= [[The Independent]] |accessdate=29 December 2013}} In 2011, Norton starred as Captain Stanhope in the classic [[First World War]] drama ''[[Journey's End]]''.{{cite web|title=Best of British: James Norton|url=http://www.shortlist.com/entertainment/best-of-british-james-norton|website=[[Shortlist (magazine)|ShortList]]|accessdate=4 November 2014}} The production toured the UK from March to June and transferred to the [[Duke of York's Theatre]] in the West End from July to September. Norton then took the role of Geoffrey in ''[[The Lion in Winter]]'' at the [[Haymarket Theatre|Theatre Royal, Haymarket]] directed by [[Trevor Nunn]], with whom Norton had worked at Cambridge in ''Cymbeline''. In the 2012 film ''[[Cheerful Weather for the Wedding (film)|Cheerful Weather for the Wedding]]'', Norton played Owen, the would-be groom of a conflicted bride.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/07/movies/cheerful-weather-for-the-wedding-with-elizabeth-mcgovern.html |title=There Will Always Be a Fantasy England: 'Cheerful Weather for the Wedding' With Elizabeth McGovern |last1=Holden |first1=Stephen |date=6 December 2012 |work= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate=20 June 2014}} He appeared in the 2013 film ''[[Rush (2013 film)|Rush]]'' as [[Formula One]] driver [[Guy Edwards]]. In the 2013 film ''[[Belle (2013 film)|Belle]]'', he played a suitor of the title character, a mixed-race lady in 18th century English society.{{cite web |url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/entertainment/movies/2014/05/21/movie-review-belle/9380533/ |title=Movie Review: 'Belle' |last1=Darling |first1=Cary |date=21 May 2014 |work= [[The Courier-Journal]] |accessdate=20 June 2014}} Norton's television appearances include the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' episode "[[Cold War (Doctor Who)|Cold War]]", in which he played a crewman on a Soviet submarine during the [[Cold War]], and ''[[Death Comes to Pemberley (TV series)|Death Comes to Pemberley]]'', based on the [[P. D. James]] novel involving characters from [[Jane Austen]]'s ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' caught up in a murder mystery. Norton was acclaimed for his role as Tommy Lee Royce, the villain of the hit crime drama ''[[Happy Valley (TV series)|Happy Valley]]''. Michael Hogan of ''The Telegraph'' wrote: "...the breakout star, seen in only a few small parts before this, has been the devilishly handsome James Norton, 29, as the heinous killer Royce, whom he has played with impressive depth".{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/10872830/8-million-people-are-currently-wishing-me-dead.html |title=Happy Valley's James Norton: '8 million people are currently wishing me dead' |last1=Hogan |first1=Michael |date=3 June 2014 |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=20 June 2014}} As the first series came to its dramatic conclusion, Norton commented, "8 million people are currently wishing me dead". Norton confirmed he would be appearing in the second series of ''Happy Valley'' at the 2015 [[BAFTA]]s.{{cite web|last1=Goodacre|first1=Kate |last2=Jeffery| first2=Morgan| url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a646593/james-norton-will-return-to-happy-valley-for-series-2.html#~pcjMRy2nfdB8|title=James Norton will return to Happy Valley for series 2|date=10 May 2015|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=10 May 2015}} Since 2014, Norton has played crime-solving vicar Sidney Chambers alongside [[Robson Green]] as Police Inspector Geordie Keating in the ITV series ''[[Grantchester (TV series)|Grantchester]]'', based on the novels by [[James Runcie]].{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/press-releases/itv-announces-cast-new-six-part-drama-grantchester |title=ITV announces the cast of new six-part drama Grantchester |date=25 March 2014 |website= ITV Press Centre |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Debnath|first1=Neela|title=Grantchester star Robson Green: ‘We’re going to lose James Norton quickly’|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/granchester-star-robson-green-were-going-to-lose-james-norton-quickly-9794245.html|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=20 October 2014}} ''Grantchester'' was his first starring role.{{cite news|title=Grantchester: James Norton talks about playing heavy-drinking vicar in new detective drama|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Grantchester-James-Norton-talks-playing-heavy/story-23046669-detail/story.html|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[Nottingham Post]]|date=7 October 2014}} A second series was broadcast in early 2016. A third series went into production in autumn 2016, and aired in both the UK and the U.S. in late spring/early summer 2017.{{cite web|last1=Tartaglione|first1=Nancy|url=http://deadline.com/2014/11/itv-grantchester-second-season-order-masterpiece-video-1201297680/|title=ITV Has Faith In ‘Grantchester’, Orders 2nd Season Of Period Mystery Series|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=19 July 2015|date=26 November 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Sarah|title=Grantchester, TV review: It took less than two minutes for James Norton to strip to his swimming trunks|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/grantchester-tv-review-it-took-less-than-two-minutes-for-james-norton-to-strip-to-his-swimming-a6908371.html|accessdate=6 March 2016|work=The Independent|date=3 March 2016}} A fourth series began filming in June 2018, and it was confirmed that this would be Norton's final series.{{cite news |title=Grantchester series 4 confirmed – but it’s set to be James Norton’s last |url=https://www.radiotimes.com/news/tv/2018-06-29/grantchester-series-4-james-norton-final-episodes-itv/ |accessdate=1 July 2018 |work=Radio Times}} He also appears in the 2014 films ''[[Northmen: A Viking Saga]]'' and ''[[Mr. Turner (film)|Mr. Turner]]'', a biographical drama on the life of the artist [[J. M. W. Turner]] by director [[Mike Leigh]].{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Alice|title=Fashion: James Norton under cover|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2014/oct/05/fashion-james-norton-modelling-coats|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=5 October 2014}} In 2015 Norton played [[Duncan Grant]] in the BBC Two mini-series about the Bloomsbury Group, ''[[Life in Squares]].''{{cite news|last1=Molloy|first1=Antonia|title=New BBC drama Life in Squares to track lives of Bloomsbury Set|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/new-bbc-drama-life-in-squares-to-track-lives-of-bloomsbury-set-9676202.html|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=18 August 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=Guy|title=Life In Squares star James Norton: 'acting is a neurotic profession, I always need to get away'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/culturenews/11755526/Life-In-Squares-star-James-Norton-acting-is-a-neurotic-profession-I-always-need-to-get-away.html|accessdate=14 September 2015|work=[[The Telegraph (UK)|The Telegraph]]|date=25 July 2015}} In 2016, Norton appeared as Prince Andrei Bolkonsky in the [[BBC]] miniseries of [[Andrew Davies (writer)|Andrew Davies]]' production of ''[[War & Peace (2016 TV series)|War & Peace]].''{{cite news|title=James Norton: ‘Weirdly, I read War & Peace while filming Happy Valley!’ (Video)|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/tv-news/news/james-norton-weirdly-i-read-war-peace-while-filming-happy-valley-video|accessdate=3 January 2016|work=What’s on TV|date=29 December 2015}} The mini-series, a co-production with [[The Weinstein Company]], allowed the cast to film in Russia.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Emma|title=The Russian Prince|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/james-norton/|accessdate=31 January 2016|work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]|date=14 January 2016}} Between March and May 2016, Norton appeared in [[Tracy Letts]]’ ''Bug'' in London's [[West End of London|West End]].{{cite news|last1=Shenton|first1=Mark|title=Tracy Letts's Bug To Be Revived at West End's Found111 with TV Star James Norton and Kate Fleetwood|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/tracy-lettss-bug-to-be-revived-at-west-ends-found111-with-tv-star-james-norton-and-kate-fleetwood-386395|accessdate=14 February 2016|work=[[Playbill]]|date=12 February 2016}} In 2016, he appeared in "[[Nosedive (Black Mirror)|Nosedive]]", an episode of the [[anthology series]] ''[[Black Mirror]]''.{{cite news|title=‘Black Mirror’ Season 3 Trailer: "No One Is This Happy’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/10/black-mirror-season-3-trailer-netflix-bryce-dallas-howard-alice-eve-james-norton-1201832611/|accessdate=7 October 2016|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=7 October 2016}} Between December 2017 and February 2018 he appeared in [[Amy Herzog]]’s ''Belleville'' at the [[Donmar|Donmar Warehouse Theatre]].{{cite web|last1=Hetrick|first1=Adam|title=James Norton and Imogen Poots Cast in Amy Herzog’s Belleville at the Donmar|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/james-norton-and-imogen-poots-cast-in-amy-herzogs-belleville-at-the-donmar|website=www.playbill.com|accessdate=15 November 2017}} As part of his preparation for his role in ''[[McMafia]]'' (2018), Norton studied the Russian martial art and health system [[systema]].{{Citation|last=Systema GB Intuitive Self Defence|title=James Norton talks about Systema training for his role in McMafia|date=2018-01-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=45PsYGX4nbw&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2018-01-09}} ==Personal life== In 2014, Norton bought a house in the [[Peckham]] area of London. Asked if he is religious — in the context of portraying a vicar in ''[[Grantchester (TV series)|Grantchester]]'' — Norton said: "Obviously I have a relationship with religion, because I went to a Catholic school and studied theology. I can't call myself religious, but I'm definitely fascinated by it". In 2015, Norton was made a trustee of the [[Royal Theatrical Support Trust]].{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/jginorton/status/675000193138429952|title=James Norton on Twitter|work=Twitter}} Norton has [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|type 1 diabetes]].{{cite news|last1=Ross |first1=Jonathan |title=Series 10 - Episode 4 |url=http://www.itv.com/hub/the-jonathan-ross-show/2a1166a0112 |accessdate=31 January 2016 |work=[[The Jonathan Ross Show]] |date=30 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202144522/http://www.itv.com/hub/the-jonathan-ross-show/2a1166a0112 |archivedate= 2 February 2016 |df= }} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film ! Year ! Title ! Role |- | 2009 | ''{{sortname|An|Education}}'' | Jenny's boyfriend |- | 2012 | ''[[Cheerful Weather for the Wedding (film)|Cheerful Weather for the Wedding]]'' | Owen |- | 2013 | ''[[Rush (2013 film)|Rush]]'' | Guy Edwards |- | 2013 | ''[[Belle (2013 film)|Belle]]'' | Oliver Ashford |- | 2014 | ''[[Mr. Turner (film)|Mr. Turner]]'' | Francis Willoughby |- | 2014 | ''[[Bonobo (film)|Bonobo]]'' | Ralph |- | 2014 | ''[[Northmen: A Viking Saga]]'' | Bjorn |- | 2017 | ''[[Hampstead (film)|Hampstead]]'' | Philip |- | 2017 | ''[[Flatliners (2017 film)|Flatliners]]'' | Jamie |- | 2019 | ''Gareth Jones'' | [[Gareth Jones (journalist)|Gareth Jones]] |- | 2019 | ''[[Little Women (2019 film)|Little Women]]'' | John Brooke |- |} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Television ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2012 | ''[[Inspector George Gently]]'' | James Blackstone | Episode: "Gently with Class" |- | 2012 | ''[[Restless (2012 miniseries)|Restless]]'' | Kolia | Miniseries |- | 2013 | ''[[Blandings (TV series)|Blandings]]'' | Jimmy Belford | Episode: "[[Pig-hoo-o-o-o-ey]]" |- | 2013 | ''[[Doctor Who]]'' | Onegin | Episode: "[[Cold War (Doctor Who)|Cold War]]" |- | 2013 | ''[[By Any Means (2013 TV series)|By Any Means]]'' | Michael Prence | Episode: "Episode 1" |- | 2013 | ''[[Death Comes to Pemberley (TV series)|Death Comes to Pemberley]]'' | Henry Alveston | 3 episodes |- | 2014–present | ''[[Happy Valley (TV series)|Happy Valley]]'' | Tommy Lee Royce | Main Cast |- | 2014–present | ''[[Grantchester (TV series)|Grantchester]]'' | Sidney Chambers | Lead Character |- | 2015 | ''[[Life in Squares]]'' | Duncan Grant | 3 episodes |- | 2015 | ''[[Lady Chatterley's Lover (2015 film)|Lady Chatterley's Lover]]'' | Sir Clifford Chatterley | TV film |- | 2016 | ''[[War & Peace (2016 TV series)|War & Peace]]'' | Prince Andrei Bolkonsky | Main Cast |- |2016 |''[[Black Mirror]]'' |Ryan |Episode: "[[Nosedive (Black Mirror)|Nosedive]]" |- |2018 |''[[McMafia]]'' |Alex Godman |Lead Character |} {| class="wikitable" |+ Video games ! revision.text:
{{About|the baseball player|the basketball player|Jerry Grote (basketball)}} {{Infobox baseball biography |name=Jerry Grote |image= |position=[[Catcher]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1942|10|6}} |birth_place=[[San Antonio, Texas]] |debutleague = MLB |debutdate=September 21 |debutyear=1963 |debutteam=Houston Colt .45s |finalleague = MLB |finaldate=October 3 |finalyear=1981 |finalteam=Los Angeles Dodgers |statleague = MLB |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.252 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=39 |stat3label=[[Run batted in|Runs batted in]] |stat3value=404 |teams= * [[Houston Colt .45s]] ({{By|1963}}–{{By|1964}}) * [[New York Mets]] ({{By|1966}}–{{By|1977}}) * [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] ({{By|1977}}–{{By|1978}}) * [[Kansas City Royals]] ({{By|1981}}) * [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] ({{By|1981}}) |highlights= * 2× [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] ([[1968 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1968]], [[1974 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1974]]) * [[World Series]] champion ({{wsy|1969}}) * [[New York Mets Hall of Fame]] }} '''Gerald Wayne Grote''' (born October 6, 1942) is an [[American people|American]] former [[Professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player. He played the majority of his [[Major League Baseball]] career as a [[catcher]] for the [[New York Mets]], catching every inning of the franchise's first two World Series appearances, and would appear in two more World Series for the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]]. He was a two-time [[All-Star]] for the [[National League]] and is regarded as one of the best defensive catchers of his era.<ref name="Jerry Grote">{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/g/groteje01.shtml |title=Jerry Grote |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref><ref name="Jerry Grote: He Caught Some of the Greats in his Career">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2yoDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA63&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false |title=Jerry Grote: He Caught Some of the Greats in his Career |author=Winkworth, Bruce |publisher=|date=May 1992 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref>
==Early life== Grote was raised in [[San Antonio, Texas]]. When he was ten years old, he and his family were caught in an F-4 [[tornado]]. His mother, father and two sisters made it to safety, however, he lost his grandmother in the storm.<ref name=Grote>{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/sports/mets/grote_survived_storm_long_before_8xp7Xfg4uA1M1b0IqIOPVP|title=Grote Survived Storm Long Before Amazin' Title Run|publisher=New York Post|date=2009-08-12 | first=Kevin | last=Kernan}}</ref> Grote attended [[Douglas MacArthur High School (San Antonio, Texas)|Douglas MacArthur High School]], where he played on the baseball team as a [[pitcher]], catcher and [[third baseman]].<ref name=sabrbio>{{sabrbio|a68fb617|Joseph Wancho|2 November 2010}}</ref> As a high school pitcher, he threw a [[no-hitter]] and a [[One-hitter (baseball)|one hitter]].<ref name=sabrbio/> Grote played for [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]] in 1962, and led the Tigers in batting average (.413), home runs (five), RBI (19), runs (29), and hits (31).<ref name="Trinity University Athletes Inducted into Hall of Fame">{{cite web |url=http://web.trinity.edu/x17336.xml |title=Trinity University Athletes Inducted into Hall of Fame |publisher=trinity.edu |accessdate=24 November 2011 }}</ref>
==Major League career==
===Houston Colt .45s=== After one season at Trinity University, Grote was signed as an amateur [[free agent]] by the [[Houston Colt .45s]] in [[1962 Houston Colt .45s season|1962]], and was assigned to play for their [[Minor League Baseball|minor league]] affiliate, the [[San Antonio Missions|San Antonio Bullets]].<ref name=sabrbio/> At the age of 20, he made his major league debut with the Colt .45s on September 21, [[1963 Houston Colt .45s season|1963]] as a late-inning defensive replacement for [[John Bateman (baseball)|John Bateman]], and hit a [[sacrifice fly]] to score [[Bob Aspromonte]] in his only at-bat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/HOU/HOU196309210.shtml|title=Philadelphia Phillies 4, Houston Colt .45s 3|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1963-09-21}}</ref> For the season he appeared in three games, including on September 27, when every starter in the Colts' line-up was a rookie.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/HOU/HOU196309270.shtml|title=New York Mets 10, Houston Colt .45s 3|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1963-09-27}}</ref>
In [[1964 Houston Colt .45s season|1964]], Grote [[Platoon system|platooned]] with Bateman behind the plate; however, the Colts also experimented with young catchers [[Dave Adlesh]] and [[John Hoffman (baseball)|John Hoffman]], as neither Grote nor Bateman hit for a very high average that season (.181 and .190, respectively).<ref name=sabrbio/> Grote was the Colts' catcher on April 23, when [[Ken Johnson (right-handed pitcher)|Ken Johnson]] became the first pitcher in major league history to lose a [[complete game]] [[no-hitter]] in nine [[inning]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/HOU/HOU196404230.shtml|title=Cincinnati Reds 1, Houston Colt .45s 0|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1964-04-23}}</ref>
In [[1965 Houston Astros season|1965]], the newly renamed [[Houston Astros]] remained unsettled behind the plate, with former [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] [[Gus Triandos]] and prospect [[Ron Brand]] being added to the mix. Grote spent the entire season with Houston's [[Triple-A (baseball)|Triple-A]] [[Pacific Coast League]] affiliate, the [[Oklahoma City 89ers]], where he batted .265 with eleven [[home run]]s. At the end of the season, he was traded to the [[New York Mets]] for pitcher [[Tom Parsons (baseball)|Tom Parsons]].<ref name="Jerry Grote Trades and Transactions">{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=groteje01 |title=Jerry Grote Trades and Transactions |publisher=Baseball Almanac |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref>
===New York Mets=== Grote became the starting catcher for the Mets immediately upon his arrival in [[New York City]]. Though he batted only .237 with three home runs in {{by|1966}}, his handling of the Mets' young pitchers and his solid defensive skills were instrumental in helping the Mets avoid 100 losses and a last place finish for the first time in franchise history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.mets.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100127&content_id=7976356&vkey=news_nym&fext=.jsp&c_id=nym|title=Inbox: Were Mets wise to stay frugal?|publisher=Marty Noble/MLB.com|date=2010-01-27}}</ref> Grote earned a reputation with his teammates and opponents as highly competitive, developing the trademark of rolling the ball to the far side of the [[pitcher's mound]] (closest to the Mets' dugout) while leaving the field after his pitcher ended an inning with a [[strikeout]]. This necessitated the opposing team's pitcher having to walk further to stoop and retrieve the ball.
In [[1968 New York Mets season|1968]], Grote was hitting over .300 at mid-season and was recognized as one of the top catchers in the National League when he was selected to be the starting catcher in the [[1968 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1968 All-Star Game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=groteje01&t=b&year=1968 |title=1968 Jerry Grote Batting Log |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref><ref name="1968 All-Star Game">{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NLS/NLS196807090.shtml |title=1968 All-Star Game |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> He became only the second Met player in franchise history after [[Ron Hunt]] to earn a starting role in an All-Star game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.mets.mlb.com/nym/history/all_stars.jsp|title=Mets All-stars|accessdate=2009-03-27}}</ref> Grote was hitless in two at-bats during the game.<ref name="1968 All-Star Game"/> He ended the year with a .282 batting average along with three [[home run]]s and 31 [[runs batted in]].<ref name="Jerry Grote"/>
The [[1969 New York Mets season|1969]] season would be a memorable one for Grote and the Mets. The [[1969 Chicago Cubs season|Chicago Cubs]] had been in first place since the beginning of the season and had a nine-game lead as late as August 15.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHC/1969-schedule-scores.shtml |title=1969 Chicago Cubs Schedule, Box Scores and Splits |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> However, the Cubs began to falter while the Mets continued to play well. When the two teams met for a two-game series on September 8, the Mets won both games to move just a half game behind the Cubs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYM/1969-schedule-scores.shtml |title=1969 New York Mets Schedule, Box Scores and Splits |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> Aside from calling [[Tom Seaver]]'s five-hit pitching performance in the second game, Grote drove in the Mets' seventh and final run of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYN/NYN196909090.shtml|title=New York Mets 7, Chicago Cubs 1|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1969-09-09}}</ref> The following day, the Mets swept the [[Montreal Expos]] in a [[Doubleheader (baseball)|doubleheader]], with Grote catching all 21 innings. Coupled with a Cubs loss, the Mets moved into first place for the first time in their history. The Mets stayed in the lead for the rest of the season, finishing with a 37-11 record in their final 48 games while the Cubs slumped to a 9-17 record in their final 26 games, and clinched the [[National League Eastern Division]] title on September 24.<ref>[https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1969-standings.shtml 1969 National League East standings at Baseball Reference]</ref><ref name="Pennant Races Don't Really Begin Until Month of July">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ACwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA29&dq=baseball+digest+miracle+mets#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=Pennant Races Don't Really Begin Until Month of July |author=Vass, George |publisher=|date=July 1996 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref>
Grote finished the season with a .252 average and produced career-highs with six home runs and 40 runs batted in, but it was his defensive skills that proved most valuable for the Mets.<ref name="Jerry Grote"/><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KDMDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA33&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false |title=Jerry Grote: Mets Most Valuable? |author=Elderkin, Phil |publisher=|date=February 1970 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> Grote posted a .991 [[fielding percentage]] and his 56.3% [[caught stealing]] percentage was second-best among National League catchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1969-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1969 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref> He was also given credit for guiding the Mets young pitching staff that led the league in victories and [[Shutout (baseball)|shutouts]] and finished second in team [[earned run average]].<ref name=sabrbio/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1969.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::none |title=1969 National League Team Statistics and Standings |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref>
The Mets went on to sweep the [[1969 Atlanta Braves season|Atlanta Braves]] in the [[1969 National League Championship Series]], but were heavy [[Underdog (term)|underdogs]] heading into the [[1969 World Series]] against the [[1969 Baltimore Orioles season|Baltimore Orioles]]. Following a 4-1 loss in the series opener with [[Cy Young award]] winner Seaver on the mound, it seemed as if the Mets had little chance against the Orioles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BAL/BAL196910110.shtml|title=1969 World Series Game One|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1969-10-11}}</ref> However, the Mets bounced back, winning the next four games to capture their first world championship.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1969_WS.shtml |title=1969 World Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> Besides catching every inning in the post-season, Grote contributed offensively with a [[Single (baseball)|single]] in Game Two to keep a ninth [[inning]] rally alive and [[Al Weis]] followed with the game-winning [[Hit (baseball)|hit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BAL/BAL196910120.shtml|title=1969 World Series Game Two|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1969-10-12}}</ref> With Game Four tied, Grote doubled to start the tenth inning, then [[pinch runner]] [[Rod Gaspar]] scored the winning run when an errant throw hit [[J.C. Martin]] on the wrist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYN/NYN196910150.shtml|title=1969 World Series Game Four|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1969-10-15}}</ref> With Grote calling the pitches, the Mets pitching staff held the Orioles hitters to a .146 batting average during the series.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1969_WS.shtml#post_batting_loser::none |title=1969 World Series Baltimore Orioles Batting Statistics |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref>
Grote and the 1969 Mets became an improbable part of baseball history. In their previous seven seasons the Mets had finished in last place five times. Their sudden turn of fortune in 1969 and their subsequent upset victory in the World Series stunned the sports world and became one of the more storied events in baseball lore.<ref name="When The Miracle Mets Shocked The Baseball World">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vybawTLKGmwC&pg=PA48&dq=miracle+mets+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=miracle%20mets%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=When The Miracle Mets Shocked The Baseball World |author=Schultz, Randy |publisher=|date=June 2009 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref> The team became known as the ''Miracle Mets''.<ref name="When The Miracle Mets Shocked The Baseball World"/>
Grote continued to provide the Mets with good defense, leading National League catchers in {{By|1970}} and {{By|1971}} in [[putouts]] and in [[range factor]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1970-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1970 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1971-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1971 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> In [[1972 New York Mets season|1972]], Grote played in only 64 games due to injuries and in late September he had surgery to remove bone chips from his right elbow.<ref name=sabrbio/>
In May [[1973 New York Mets season|1973]], Grote broke a bone in his right arm when he was hit by a pitch and went on the [[disabled list]] for two months.<ref name=sabrbio/> When he returned in mid-July, the Mets began winning, climbing from last place on August 30 to win the National League Eastern Division pennant.<ref name="Pennant Races Don't Really Begin Until Month of July"/><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ui4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA20&dq=pennant+races+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pennant%20races%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=Six Greatest Pennant Races of the Last 50 Years |author=Vass, George |publisher=|date=September 1991 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYM/1973.shtml |title=1973 New York Mets Batting, Pitching, & Fielding Statistics |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> They then proceeded to defeat the heavily favored [[1973 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]] in the [[1973 National League Championship Series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_NLCS.shtml |title=1973 National League Championship Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> In the [[1973 World Series|World Series]], the Mets took the [[1973 Oakland Athletics season|Oakland Athletics]] to the seventh and final game, before they were defeated.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_WS.shtml |title=1973 World Series |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> As he had in 1969, Grote caught every [[inning]] of every post-season game for the Mets in {{by|1973}}.<ref name=sabrbio/> Looking back on his two pennant-winning seasons with the Mets, Grote said, "It (the 1969 season) was no miracle. Now, '73 was a miracle."<ref name=Grote/>
In {{by|1974}}, Grote was batting .287 with four home runs and 27 runs batted in to earn his second [[1974 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star selection]], however, injuries were beginning to take their toll and he split the catching duties with [[Duffy Dyer]].<ref name=sabrbio/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NLS/NLS197407230.shtml|title=1974 All-Star Game|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1974-07-23}}</ref> Grote rebounded in [[1975 New York Mets season|1975]], posting a career-high .295 batting average in 119 games and led all National League catchers with a .995 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name="Jerry Grote"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1975-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1975 National League Fielding Leaders |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> At [[Veterans Stadium]] on July 4, 1975, Grote stepped in as a [[pinch hitter]] against longtime teammate [[Tug McGraw]], who had been traded to the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] during the off-season. With the Mets down 3-2, Grote connected for a game winning two run home run.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/PHI/PHI197507040.shtml|title=New York Mets 4, Philadelphia Phillies 3|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1975-07-04}}</ref>
By the [[1977 New York Mets season|1977]] season, [[John Stearns]] had taken over as the Mets' starting catcher as back injuries continued to plague Grote and in August, after twelve seasons with the Mets, he was traded to the [[1977 Los Angeles Dodgers season|Los Angeles Dodgers]] for two players to be named later.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19770901&id=tZAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i6EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4954,117747&hl=en Mets swap Grote]</ref>
===Los Angeles Dodgers and Kansas City Royals=== Shortly after joining the Dodgers, Grote struck out in his only career at-bat against former battery-mate Tom Seaver, who was now with the Reds.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/LAN/LAN197709150.shtml|title=Cincinnati Reds 3, Los Angeles Dodgers 2|publisher=Baseball-reference.com|date=1977-09-15}}</ref> During his two seasons with the Dodgers, he played part-time as a backup to [[Steve Yeager]] and appeared in two World Series against the [[New York Yankees]]. He retired from professional baseball after the {{by|1978}} season, only to be lured out of retirement in [[1981 Kansas City Royals season|1981]] by the [[Kansas City Royals]], who were experiencing a shortage of catchers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Jerry_Grote_1941 |title=Jerry Grote |publisher=baseballlibrary.com |accessdate=2 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604034220/http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Jerry_Grote_1941 |archivedate= 4 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> On June 3, {{By|1981}}, at the age of 38, Grote went 3 for 4 with a [[Grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] home run, a double, and a [[stolen base]], driving in a team-record seven runs.<ref name=sabrbio/> After another short stint with the Dodgers, he retired for good after the {{by|1981}} season.
==Career statistics== In a sixteen-year major league career, Grote played in 1,421 [[Games played|games]], accumulating 1,092 [[Hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,339 [[at bats]] for a .252 career batting average along with 39 home runs and 404 [[runs batted in]].<ref name="Jerry Grote"/> He ended his career with a .991 fielding percentage,<ref name="Jerry Grote"/> which at the time of his retirement was eighth highest all-time among catchers. On April 22, {{By|1970}}, Grote set a major league record with 20 [[putout]]s in a game when Tom Seaver threw 19 [[strikeout]]s against the [[1970 San Diego Padres season|San Diego Padres]].<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ry4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=bob+schmidt+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=bob%20schmidt%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=Letters To The Editor |publisher=|date=September 1990 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NYN/NYN197004220.shtml |title=April 22, 1970 Padres-Mets box score |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref> He is the Mets all-time leader in games played as a catcher (1,176).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/mostgame.htm |title=Most Games Caught for Team |publisher=The Encyclopedia of Baseball Catchers |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref> Grote caught 116 [[Shutouts in baseball|shutouts]] in his career, ranking him 15th all-time among catchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/tmonth1.htm |title=Career Shutouts Caught |publisher=The Encyclopedia of Baseball Catchers |accessdate=1 February 2011 }}</ref>
Grote called the pitches for some of the most outstanding pitchers of his era, including Tom Seaver, [[Jerry Koosman]], Tug McGraw, [[Nolan Ryan]], [[Tommy John]], [[Don Sutton]], and [[Dan Quisenberry]].<ref name="Jerry Grote: He Caught Some of the Greats in his Career"/> He possessed a strong and accurate throwing arm against opposing [[baserunner]]s. Hall of Fame inductee [[Lou Brock]] found Grote to be one of the most difficult catchers on which to attempt a [[stolen base]],<ref name="Jerry Grote: He Caught Some of the Greats in his Career"/> and though [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Hall of Fame]] catcher [[Johnny Bench]] was the perennial [[Gold Glove Award|Gold Glove winner]] during their careers in the National League together, Bench once said of Grote, "If Grote and I were on the same team, I would be playing [[third base]]."<ref name=Grote/>
<div align="left"> {| border="1" cellpadding="2" |Seasons |Games |AB |Runs |Hits |2B |3B |HR |RBI |SB |BB |SO |HBP |Avg. |Slg. |Fld% |CS% |- |16 |1421 |4339 |352 |1092 |160 |22 |39 |404 |15 |399 |600 |26 |.252 |.326 |.991 |38% |}
==Post retirement and honors== After his playing career had ended, Grote spent {{by|1985}} as [[Manager (baseball)|manager]] of the [[Lakeland Tigers]] and the [[Birmingham Barons]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=grote-001ger#standard_managing |title=Jerry Grote Manager Record |publisher=Baseball Reference |accessdate=2 November 2010 }}</ref> In {{by|1989}}, he played for the [[St. Lucie Legends]] in the [[Senior Professional Baseball Association]].<ref name="Jerry Grote: He Caught Some of the Greats in his Career"/> He was inducted into the Texas Baseball Hall of Fame in 1991, and the [[New York Mets Hall of Fame]] in {{By|1992}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tbhof.org/bio/1991/biogrote.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090811004645/http://www.tbhof.org/bio/1991/biogrote.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 August 2009 |title=Jerry Grote at the Texas Hall of Fame |publisher=tbhof.org |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyork.mets.mlb.com/nym/history/nym_history_halloffame.jsp |title=New York Mets Hall of Fame |publisher=mlb.com |accessdate=3 November 2010 }}</ref> In {{by|1998}}, he was inducted into the San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/sports/San_Antonio_Sports_Hall_of_Fame_members_and_nominees.html |title=Jerry Grote at the San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame |publisher=mysanantonio.com |accessdate=3 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709131431/http://www.mysanantonio.com/sports/San_Antonio_Sports_Hall_of_Fame_members_and_nominees.html |archivedate= 9 July 2009 |df= }}</ref> On October 8, 2011, Grote was inducted into the [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]] Athletic Hall of Fame.<ref name="Trinity University Athletes Inducted into Hall of Fame"/> After retirement, Grote continued to raise prize Texas longhorns on his ranch near [[Austin, Texas]].<ref name=sabrbio/> He appeared as a Mystery Guest on the [[television]] [[game show]] ''[[What's My Line?]]''.<ref>*{{cite book | first=Gil | last=Fates | year= 1978 | title= What's My Line? TV's Most Famous Panel Show | publisher= Cornerstone Library | location= New York| isbn= 0-346-12396-8}}</ref>
Grote can be heard as [[color commentator]] with Mike Capps on the Round Rock Express (PCL) radio home broadcasts (2010)--and on the Internet on MiLB.com.
==Personal life== Grote and his wife learned [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] in August 1974. Of their practice Grote said, "it's like an instant seven or eight hours' sleep. … Because of it, my wife and I probably are more in love, closer, and more dependent on each other than we've ever been in 13 years of marriage."<ref>{{cite news|last=Richman|first=Milton|title=Jerry Grote changes ways|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=860&dat=19760527&id=7EJPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b48DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2449,3254940|accessdate=25 January 2014|newspaper=Ellensburg Daily Record|date=May 27, 1976|page=10}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Baseballstats|mlb=115194|espn=155|br=g/groteje01|fangraphs=1005092&position=C|cube=12211|brm=grote-001ger}} *[http://www.jerrygrote.com/ Jerry Grote home page] *{{sabrbio|a68fb617|Joseph Wancho|2 November 2010}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=zCoDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA75&dq=baseball+digest+miracle+mets#v=onepage&q=&f=false "69 Mets Remembered: Where Have They Gone?", ''Baseball Digest'', August 1999] *[http://www.ultimatemets.com/profile.php?PlayerCode=0120 Ultimate Mets database: Jerry Grote] *[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=groteje01 Baseball Almanac: Jerry Grote]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Indian politician | name = Jogen Chowdhury | image = Jogen Chowdhury - Kolkata 2012-10-03 0468.JPG | image_size = 200px | caption = Jogen Chowdhury at [[Academy of Fine Arts, Kolkata]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1939|2|16}} | birth_place = [[Daharpara Village]], [[Faridpur District|Faridpur]], [[East Bengal]] | birth_name = | office = [[Indian Parliament |Member of Parliament]] ([[Rajya Sabha]]) | term_start = 3 April 2014 | constituency = [[West Bengal]] | party = [[All India Trinamool Congress]] | occupation = painter | website = http://www.jogenchowdhury.net/
}} '''Jogen Chowdhury''' (born 16 February 1939) is an eminent Indian painter and considered an important painter of 21st century India. He lives and works in [[Santiniketan]]. He graduated from the [[Government College of Art & Craft, Kolkata]] and subsequently at [[École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts]], Paris in 1967. He has immense contribution in inspiring young artists of India. Jogen Chowdhury had developed his individual style after his return from Paris. His most famous paintings are in ink, water colour and pastel. He has painted in oil medium as well.
Lines and its tactile characteristic to enhance colours is an important material in Indian Art for ages. Jogen Chowdhury himself is a master of lines and he has mastered to make the curves depict the character of his figures. By careful distortion of the form he imparts the air of caricature in his figures, figures of men and women. The figure is always the most important and conveys all the artist has to express. Colour, he uses though, is to provide matter into the form. [[R. Siva Kumar]] has lucidly described Jogen's works in the following excerpt:"The pulse and rhythm of Jogen Chowdhury’s art comes from a filial affinity to nature and milieu. In Chowdhury’s more recent works the sensory experiences of cloth, bolsters, sofas and the human body are cross-projected to produce an uncanny world of tran-substantiated tumescence and flaccidness. Mnemic displacements and personal associations add to the symbolic ambivalence of his motifs, making his images come closer to inexplicable experiences than to explicit signs. In the postures of some figures we feel an animal sentience, in the ripe anatomy of others we savour a fruity succulence. The figures are wrought by a combination of decorative wilfulness and expressive distortion and are imbued with an effusive sensuality. Chowdhury’s art is rich in suggestions; it is to be apprehended without bracketing our fund of knowledge, experience or memories, but also cannot be narrativised without trivialising it, without depleting its sensory particularities."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cimaartindia.com/artists.php?a=jogen-chowdhury |title=Jogen Chowdhury |work=Center of International Modern Art (CIMA)}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life and education=== Jogen was born in Daharpara Village, a village in the Faridpur district of Bangladesh in 1939. His father Pramatha Nath Chowdhury was a Brahmin zamindar. Jogen received the interest on art from his parents as both his parents were artists. Pramatha Nath was interested in Hindu mythological incidents and characters. He had painted several mythological scenes from the village theatres. He had also sculpted various Hindu deities. Jogen's mother was an expert in [[Rangoli|Alpana]] drawings.
Jogen Chowdhury was born and brought-up in a village culture and atmosphere. Just before partition Jogen along with his father came to Calcutta; the rest of the family moved to Calcutta in 1948, after the partition. The family stayed at his uncle's quarter. Here Jogen painted his first painting, on the wall.<ref name="Palette Art Gallery">[http://www.paletteartgallery.com/artistbiography.asp?artistid=15 The palette Art Gallery ''Jogen Chowdhury'''s biography and selected works]</ref>
In 1951, Jogen's family moved to Saheednagar Colony, [[Dhakuria]].
Jogen was admitted to the [[Government College of Art & Craft, Kolkata]] in 1955 wherefrom he graduated by 1960. His first job was as an art teacher in Howrah zilla school. After two years in 1962, he was employed as Designer in the Handloom Board, Calcutta.
===His youth=== In 1965, he went to Paris to study in Ecole des Beaux Arts, in William Hayter's Atelier 17. Afterwards he spent five months in London.
He returned to India in early 1968. He was appointed as a textile designer in the Handloom Board in Chennai. In 1970, he joined the [[Calcutta Painters]] Group. His first collection of poems [[Hridoy Train Beje Othey]] was also published in the same year.
He quit his job at the Madras Handloom Board in 1972 to join the Art Gallery of [[Rashtrapati Bhavan]], New Delhi as a Curator. Due to this new job, he moved to New Delhi. He founded the [[Gallery 26 and Artists' Forum]] in New Delhi in 1975 along with some leading painters of New Delhi. In 1986, Jogen represented India in the 'Festival of Art' in Baghdadwi.
===Santiniketan=== In 1987, Jogen Chowdhury joined [[Kala Bhavan]], Santiniketan as professor of painting. Beside his numerous paintings, exhibitions, he has written extensively on contemporary art. He was also appointed as Juror in several exhibitions.
==Political career== In 2014, Jogen Chowdhury has been elected as a member of [[Rajya Sabha]] from [[Trinamool Congress]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Trinamool Congress wins four Rajya Sabha seats in West Bengal; Congress bags two in Assam, three in Andhra Pradesh|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/trinamool-congress-wins-four-rajya-sabha-seats-in-west-bengal-congress-bags-two-in-assam-three-in-an-480705|publisher=[[NDTV]]|accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.india.gov.in/my-government/indian-parliament/jogen-chowdhury-prof |series=Profile |title=Jogen Chowdhury, Prof. |work=Indian Parliament}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://osianama.com/mast-art-0000188 Jogen Chowdhury Artworks and Public Auction Prices and Economic Data] * [http://www.saffronart.com/artists/jogen-chowdhury "Jogen Chowdhury Profile,Interview and Artworks"] {{commons category}} * [http://www.gallerienvya.com "Gallerie Nvyā – Artist/ View all/ Jogen Chowdhury"] * [http://www.paletteartgallery.com/artists-list/artist-info/157 The palette Art Gallery ''Jogen Chowdhury'''s biography and selected works]. * [http://www.cimaartindia.com/NewCima/Artists/JOGENCHOWDHURY.htm The CIMA Art Gallery ''Jogen Chowdhury'''s biography and selected works]. * [http://www.contemporaryindianart.com/jogen_chowdhury.htm Contemporary Indian Art ''Jogen Chowdhury'''s biography and selected works]. * [http://www.artnet.com/artist/649507/jogen-chowdhury.html Artnet.com ''Jogen Chowdhury'''s selected works on sale].
{{Authority control}}
